title: woman sawed off hand make insurance claim
story: The -year-old enlisted the help of her family in an apparent injury claim fraud, according to detectives in Slovenia.She was rushed to hospital in the capital Ljubljana claiming that she was the victim of a horric accident while cutting branches.But the woman left the severed hand at home in a deliberate attempt to ensure the injury was permanent, cops claim.She and a relative have been arrested and each face up to eight years in prisonconvicted, BBC News reports.They allegedly took out an insurance policy in recent weeks and had stood to gain around €, .The money would have been paid out in monthly instalments worth €,under their policy.Two other family members had been arrested on suspicion of involvement in the alleged fraud earlier this year but were later released.The severed hand was recovered by authorities in time for medics to sew it back on, officials say.

title: meghan markle schoolmate shares picture princess
story: Actress Katharine McPhee revealed she had performed in school musicals with Meghan Markle as a teen - with the now royal recognising her when they met last week.Speaking on Good Morning Britain, the -year-old American actress said: I went to school with Meghan Markle, I was in middle school, she was in high school.My sister was in her class, they were the same age.She was always lovely, always talented and always put together.Katharine, who is London starring in the West end production Waitress, laughed as the flashback photograph was again shown onscreen, showing the two students smiling in outfits for their school musical.The photograph shows the pair in full make-up and sporting bright red lips for the stage show.Sharing a caption of the pic, Katharine last week wrote: Meghan and I did musicals together as kids.She grew up to be the Duchess of Sussex and I grew up to star on the West End, so same leyou ask me.They both appear to be fresh off the stage and still in costume, although Katharine didn’t reveal which production they starred in.Both Meghan and Katharine grew up in Los Angeles, with pregnant Meghan three years older, but it wasn’t widely known that they were friends.And Katharine revealed she had been flattered that the Duchess of Sussex had remembered her, as well as her sister who had been in the same grade as her, when she met her again at the WE Day UK event at Wembley Arena in London last week.She revealed: I just saw her last week and I dont have a picture even though there is one out there but you know, the royals have to approve of everything.I did get to reunite with her, and it was so sweet. She remembered me but she remembered my sister as well because they were in actual class together.Katharine, who is currently in London for the Broadway show waitress, even extended an invite to the performance to her old school pal.She said: We did invite her - were going to try to get her to come to the show.Meghan went on to become a successful actress, getting her big break in the legal drama Suits in .Katharine, also an actress as well as a singer, was a runner-up in the fth season of American Idol, and released a debut album in .She went on to release four more albums, and also had roles in Ugly Betty, Community, CSI:NY, Family Guy and The House Bunny.Katharine is currently starring in the West End production of Waitress, which opens at the Adelphi Theatre on February .

title: wetherspoons museum hotel jobs wolverhampton
story: Plans to renovate The Moon Under Water pub in Wolverhampton have now been approved by the local council.The Black Country boozer will be expanded and the floor above it, which has been empty for the last  years, converted into a hotel.It will tell the story of the leading British boozing institution and create  jobs.Businessman Tim Martin opened the first Wetherspoons in  which led to the creation of a chain of much loved no-fuss boozers, where any time of day is suitable for a full English and a pint.Its now established a UK-wide reputation as a dependable friend offering punters cheap dinners and a unique carpet experience.And now the museum and hotel are set to pour new le into a pub which has stood empty for more than  years.Wetherspoon spokesman Eddie Gershon said: We have great plans for the popular The Moon Under Water pub.We believe this will be great for the pub, its customers and just as importantly the city itself.We feel the museum will prove popular with people who want to know more of the history of the company and see artefacts from the past.The fact that Wetherspoons wishes to house it in Wolverhampton is positive for the city.The Moon Under Water is on the ground floor of Wolverhamptons sprawling former Co-op department store building.The , square feet Art Deco space was a jewel in the citys crown for decades but has stood empty for more than  years, with only the ground floor still open for business.From the day it opened in , customers travelled from across the Midlands to shop there but in recent years the upstairs storeys have been boarded up with crumbling walls, collapsed ceilings and rotten window frames.Wetherspoon operates around  pubs, including the chain of Lloyds No  bars and a growing number of Wetherspoon hotels.

title: what time is the brexit vote and what are the possible outcomes
story: But what time is the vote and what are the possible upshots we can expect  Heres what we know.May is expected to chair a cabinet meeting on Tuesday morning before the motion is debated in Parliament in the afternoon.MPs Meaningful vote on the PM’s revised deal would then be held at pm.Mrs May lost by a thumping  votes in January.During yesterdays rollercoaster day in Brexit:Theresa May will hold a second vote on her Brexit deal today - and could still suffer another crushing lossBrexiteers dont think its enough to win them over.A  of eight Brexiteer ‘lawyers’ – including DUP Westminster leader Nigel Dodds – will rule whether they believe Mrs May has done enough later today.If Mays deal is rejected, a further vote has been promised for March  on whether the UK should leave without a deal.If that No Deal is rejected, MPs could also get a vote on Thursday on whether to request a delay to Brexit from the EU.Now is the time to come together, to back this improved Brexit deal, and to deliver on the instruction of the British people, she begged MPs.A spokesperson for kingmaker MPs the DUP said last night: We note the Prime Ministers latest statement and update on our EU exit negotiations. These publications need careful analysis.We will be taking appropriate advice, scrutinising the text line by line and forming our own Judgement.Labours Sir Keir Starmer said the tweaks adds nothing to the deal and it still wouldnt be good enough for them to get behind.Tory Damian Collins said tonight: I will be voting against the government’s motion on EU withdrawal. Nothing has really changed since last November. We have the power to apply to an arbitration  to leave the back stop, but not the right to leave by ourselves.Top Tory Jacob Rees-Mogg said it was too early to tell but said it was clearly a step in the right direction.Brexiteer Steve Baker said last night he was waiting to see the text of the deal, telling Sky News: We may or may not be able to support it.Britains departure deadline is pm on Friday, March , .In between this date and December , , some form of transition period is expected.The grace period will allow businesses and others to prepare for the day the new post-Brexit rules between the UK and EU begin.Free movement will continue throughout the transition period.The UK will be able to make its own trade deals, however, they will not come into force until January , .Future relations between the UK and EU have been subject to extensive negotiations, but it is not yet known how things will work in the long term.Both sides hope they can agree within six months about issues such as trade, travel and security.The deal could then be given the go ahead in time for the day the UK leaves.

title: student stung scorpion plane seat canada
story: Student Quin Maltais said she felt a tickling sensation followed by a piercing pain as she was nipped by the venomous critter.She leapt to her feet and found the scorpion crawling into the fold of the seat on the Air Transat jet in Canada.Quin how she started to feel a fluttering motion on her lower back near the end of a four-hour flight from Toronto to Calgary.She told CBC: I just kind of ignored it.As soon as the lights turned off, closer to when were literally about to land, I felt the piercing pain on my lower back, like, oh, my God, something bit me.She said she was freaking out, trying to grab her jumper, but couldnt take off her seatbelt to see what it was.Quin added: The lights turned on, I looked into the ball of bundled sweater that I had but nothing was there.I looked behind me on the seat and then I saw movement and there was a scorpion that was in the fold toward the back of the chair.It was on my back for the past  minutes. It was like four inches maybe.She claims a stewardess initially tried to claim what she felt was a only gum wrapper - but then she checked again and spotted the scorpion between the seats.Paramedics escorted Quin off the plane when it landed at .pm on February .She said: I had a full-fledged panic attack. Paramedics had to kind of keep me strapped to a heart monitor for a while cause I was just unable to calm down.Transat said the scorpion was captured once all passengers had got off the plane.The airline said it did not know how it got there. Staff handed it to authorities.A spokesman told CBC: Although this is an extremely rare situation, it can unfortunately occur.Our teams followed the protocols in place and a complete inspection of the aircraft, as well as an extermination process, were carried out.Scorpions pack a powerful sting in their tails, but most species are not dangerous to humans.Last month terrying video showed a fearsome -inch scorpion crawling on overhead lockers on a Lion Air jet bound for Jakarta.And in  a scorpion fell on a passengers head and stung his hand on a United Airlines flight from Mexico to Calgary.

title: kate middleton childrens centre visit
story: The Duchess of Cambridge was all smiles as she headed into the Henry Fawcett Childrens Centre, in Lambeth, South London, this morning to learn about the work done to support young kids and their families.The -year-old donned a £ shirt by Gucci and £ trousers by Jigsaw for the low-key visit.The trousers are the same that Kate wore for a visit to Cyprus last year - with the wide-legged style similar to that favoured by in-law Meghan Markle.Despite rumours of a rt between the royal women before Christmas, the pair seemed delighted to see each other at the Commonwealth Day service yesterday.Flying solo today, Kate will join parents and toddlers taking part in sessions offered by the Lambeth Early Action Partnership, and Parent and Infant Relationship Service during the morning visit.The mum-of-three has prioritised visits to organisations that focus on Englands youth this year - visiting a number of schools and child play centres in the past few weeks.Last month, she spoke with children at teachers at two London schools to mark Childrens Mental Health Week.And at the start of the year, she chatted happily with young students at Islington Community Garden.But the duchess was stumped when one cheeky student asked herthe Queen had ever eaten pizza.The -year-old royal has previously spoken out about the importance of supporting kids mental health, encouraging them to be comfortable in their own skin.She even penned a personal essay about mental health issues with Huffington Post UK, writing: The mental health of our children must be seen as every bit as important as their physical health.For too long we have been embarrassed to admit when our children need emotional or psychiatric help, worried that the stigma associated with these problems would be detrimental to their futures.The mum has been a patron of charity PlaceBe since  and has worked with husband Prince William and Prince Harry in their Heads Together campaign.Tonight, Kate will attend the Portrait Gala  to meet members of the gallerys Youth Forum and view artwork produced by some of the National Portrait Gallerys outreach programmes.It is the third gala she has attended and will raise money to support the gallerys work.It comes after a busy day for the Royal Family yesterday, with the senior members attending a Commonwealth Day service at Westminster Abbey.Meghan and Kate greeted each other with a warm kiss on each cheek as the Queen arrived.Speaking exclusively to Fabulous Online, body language expert Judi said: It was clear Kate and Meghan were keen to signal bonds of warm friendship yesterday, rather than the either distant or over-congruent displays from the last couple of outings.

title: brexit deal backbenchers plea theresa may
story: A text went to Ministers on Sunday with a list of Tory MPs that whips believe could still shoot down Theresa May’s agreement.Insiders said the list appeared “desperate” given it included arch Brexiteer Steve Baker – the self-styled shop steward of the European Research Group and a fierce critic of the PM’s deal.One source said: “His name raised a few eyebrows. title: brexit 5 fast facts you
story: NewsBrexit:  fast facts you need to know this morning with  days to goToday is D-Day. MPs will vote from pm on Theresa Mays Brexit deal after an th-hour dash to Strasbourg - and the result will decide our futureShareCommentsByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  MAR Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news uk-news offline video theresa-faces-press-after-crunch-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news politics  , theme : # , title : Mirror Politics ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news politics  , theme : # , title : Mirror Politics ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true""Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailIts D-Day for Theresa Mays Brexit deal. MPs will hold their meaningful vote at pm on the -page pact she reached with the EU. Two months after her deal fell by a record defeat, and just  days before were supposed to leave, Mrs May will give Parliament a chance to have the final say. Last night she made a frenzied final dash to Strasbourg where she came up with a final offer.But she still faces defeat after several Tories and Labour rejected it. That would lead to a vote on No Deal Brexit tomorrow night followed by a vote on delaying Brexit on Thursday.The Commons chamber was packed past pm last night as MPs traded angry recriminations over the last-minute deal. Here are the five quick things you need to know as you wake up and go to work.  Theresa May last night claimed she had won legally binding changes to her plans after MPs demanded a change to the Irish border backstop.The backstop is an insurance clause that would keep the UK in EU customs rules from ,there is no agreement to keep the Irish border open. MPs feared the EU could use the clause to trap the UK in the backstop, holding the country to ransom in trade talks. So the UK and EU agreed a “joint interpretative instrument” to -page deal that, Mrs May claims, would provide a mechanism for the UK to quit the backstopthe EU is showing bad faith. It will give a key role to an arbitration  - who will hear appealsthe UK feels the EU is trying to keep it in the Northern Irish backstop against its will. Separately the new deal commits the parties to coming up with alternative arrangements by December .  In January Theresa May vowed to win “not a further exchange of letters, but a signicant and legally binding change to the withdrawal agreement.” She hasnt done that. The documents she has published are in addition to the -page agreement. They dont change its contents. Theresa May also promised to seek either a time limit, a unilateral exit mechanism, or alternative arrangements to the backstop. She hasnt done that. There is no time limit, and alternative arrangements are a future hope rather than being in place now. As for a unilateral exit mechanism... she may claim she has got it, but MPs will say dferent. It only worksthe UK can prove the EU is trying to trap us in the backstop against our will. And thats very subjective. Even Mrs Mays own statement to Parliament today admits her new deal “reduces the risk of being held in the backstop. It doesnt eliminate it. Labours Keir Starmer says its basically the same deal. . MPs look like theyll still vote against  While Remainers branded it a fig leaf, some Tories wafted over to back the Prime Ministers deal overnight. But thats nowhere near the  people she needs to change their votes from no to yes to pass it. And the DUP, whose votes are crucial, said they would judge the PM by her promises in January - which she hasnt kept . Labours Keir Starmer said it was a pile of broken promises. Remain-backing former attorney general Dominic Grieve told the BBC: “It doesn’t allow the UK the right to terminate the backstop at a time of its own choosing. Ultimately I dont think this document thats been produced makes any signicant dference. Brexiteer Tory ringleader Steve Baker said: I think this falls very far short of what the government whipped us to vote for. And his right-wing comrade Jacob Rees-Mogg said it was “unquestionably a step in the right direction,” but would not commit his vote. Even Iain Duncan Smith, one of the more hopeful-sounding Brexiteers, urged the PM not to rush things through and said she should delay the vote by  hours.  Before .am today, Attorney General Geoffrey Cox will publish his legal advice on the Brexit deal. MPs will scan his text keenly to seeit agrees the deal meets with promises by the Prime Minister. If he does, it will give many Tories political cover to back the deal. But even then, it may not be enough for Theresa May to win. Hard Brexiteers fume that Mr Cox was also involved in negotiating the deal - so hes marking his own homework. Labour are demanding he make a separate House of Commons statement at .pm, before the main debate on the Brexit deal kicks off this afternoon.. Oh, meanwhile, the City is planning a Brexit war room The Financial Conduct Authority has plans in place for a financial war room to take action in the event of a no-deal Brexit. It will oversee the necessary IT changes to keep Britains banking sector operationwe crash out without a deal. An FCA spokesman said: As part of our planning for all scenarios we have put in place contingency measures in the event of a hard Brexit. We will have teams in place throughout the weekend of exit to monitor the situation and respond as needed, working closely with the Treasury and the Bank of England.

title: brexit dont expect sensible outcome
story: NewsAnalysisBrexit: Dont expect a sensible outcome - we are in the banter timeline nowWe live in a parallel universe where only the most darkly hilarious storyline is possible, and Brexit is the proofShareCommentsByMikey SmithPolitical Correspondent:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR NewsAnalysis "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailLast night, as Theresa May sent word that she’s secured more Brexit concessions from Strasbourg, the UK’s anti-EU party had an announcement to make. UKIP has polled at almost % for much of the decade and won the  European Elections. Their core purpose - their very reason to exist - is to ensure Britain leaves the EU. This was a big moment for them. Perhaps the party’s biggest moment since their referendum night victory. The tweet read: “PATRIOTS SUBSCRIBE TO PEWDIEPIE” Those of you who are familiar with science fiction will be aware of alternate realities and parallel universes. They’re plot devices often invoked in order to liven up a franchise which is under threat of going stale. The characters you know and love are all present, but there’s a twist. Up is down, left is right. Some detail is dferent, with entertaining results. In Star Trek, you have the Mirror Universe, where Spock has a goatee and people eat Kelpians for lunch.   Marvel Comics has dozens of parallel worlds. In some of them, Spider-Man is a cartoon pig. Perhaps most famous is Back to the Future Part II, in which a tiny change to history makes Bf Tannen a billionaire and turns Hill Valley into Vegas on crack. Most people assume we live in the prime timeline - the one where everything is normal and as it should be. I have long suspected we are living in an alternate timeline. This is the Banter Timeline - where all the things that were supposed to happen don’t, and are replaced by the most objectively hilarious alternative. It was created when a bored London student in the mid-s said to a friend: “Wouldn’t it be funnythat posh blonde bloke off of Have I Got News For You was mayor of London ” And the universe said “Yes. Yes it would.”   “Tell you what, itd be a laughBrexit won, wouldnt it ” “Yeah, and how aboutDonald Trump had a hit TV show ” “The guy from Home Alone   Dream big, my dude. Let’s make him President of the United States.” “Amazing. Now, who’s the most entertaining person we can get to be leader of the Labour Party ” It’s certainly endearing that there are still people out there who believe Brexit is all going to be resolved with some kind of sensible deal, which sees Britain set sail as a buccaneering independent coastal nation. But we’re in the Banter Timeline. In the Banter Timeline, only the most darkly hilarious outcome is possible. Lets face it, weve already had the Attorney General yelling BOLLOCKS at prominent TV news anchors this morning, so I dont know why youd expect anything more sensible from the rest of the day. Of all the plausible outcomes of this evenings vote, Theresa May’s deal getting another embarrassing drubbing from MPs certainly has the most comedic potential. Beyond that, only the god of banter knows what delights are in store. Perhaps MPs will plump for no-deal in their vote tomorrow, plunging us into a Mad Max-style apocalypse, where all there is to eat is freeze dried fish from bags.   Or maybe the most banterric outcome is for MPs to block no-deal AND block an extension to Article  in upcoming votes, leaving us in some weird limbo state. Maybe the Queen will get involved. Maybe Jacob Rees-Mogg will be Prime Minister come June, and will have passed a law demanding a butler on every street corner by Christmas. But whatever the next step, we should probably give up on the idea of this all being sorted out in a calm, sensible fashion. Sorry everyone, that’s a dferent timeline.

title: brexit keir starmer savages theresa
story: NewsBrexit: Keir Starmer savages Theresa Mays new deal in fiery Commons statementLabours Shadow Brexit Secretary swept into full lawyer mode for a damning statement shooting down the Prime Ministers new dealShareCommentsByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news politics video watch-kier-starmers-response-commons-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news politics  , theme : # , title : Mirror Politics ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news politics  , theme : # , title : Mirror Politics ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true""Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailLabours Keir Starmer tonight savaged Theresa Mays Brexit deal in a fiery House of Commons statement. The former Director of Public Prosecutions swept into full lawyer mode as he held aloft hundreds of pages of documents in a furious attack. He spoke after Theresa May jetted to Strasbourg for a last-ditch deal with the EU to persuade MPs to vote for her Brexit deal tomorrow night. Her deputy, David Lidington, told MPs the government had secured legally-binding changes that strengthen and improve the -page Brexit deal. He said a new joint instrument will prevent the EU trapping the UK in the Northern Ireland backstop - a clause that would extend EU customs rules over the UK - indefinitely.   And there will be a joint statement supplementing the future political declaration on trade setting out a negotiating track for changes to the Irish backstop. But Mr Lidington prompted shouts of uproar when he said MPs must now back the deal... to avoid a crisis. Jeremy Corbyn insisted that her negotiations had failed and called on MPs to reject the deal. And Sir Keir shot down Mr Lidingtons argument by saying Theresa May had promised to change the Brexit deal itself - and achieved no such thing.  Waving a fat wad of legal papers, Labours Shadow Brexit Secretary asked: Is a single word of the Withdrawal Agreement dferent now to the document that was agreed on November   He added: It sounds again asnothing has changed. Andthat is right, the Prime minister is left with a pile of broken promises. Its as much a matter of trust as substance. Sir Keir branded the situation absurd and made a cruel joke at the Cabinet Office ministers expense.  I don’t complain for not having advance notice of his statement, he told MPs. I’m not sure HES got advance notice. Sir Keir said MPs will be disappointed but not surprised. He said Labour would examine the plans, but boasting of signicant change when just repeating a January statement is not going to take anyone very far. Theresa May, speaking in Strasbourg, said the deal would honour the referendum result and is good for both the UK and the EU. She said she had secured legally binding changes to the Irish backstop.  But Labour MPs lined up to savage the new arrangement. Wes Streeting tweeted: Sat in the Chamber genuinely stunned by the futility and incompetence of the Government’s statement. We’re days away from exit. This is just smoke and mirrors. Labour MP Tracy Brabin added: Late night statement and still no wiser. He’s saying words but none seem to make sense. The new letter agreement isn’t part of the withdrawal agreement we will be voting on tomorrow.

title: brexit what deal theresa promise
story: NewsBrexit: What deal did Theresa May promise MPs - and what did she actually get Theresa May claims shes won "legally binding" changes to her Brexit plan ahead of a crunch vote tonight. So weve compared what she asked for to what she actually gotShareCommentsByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  MAR Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news video theresa-urges-mps-vote-brexit-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news politics  , theme : # , title : Mirror Politics ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news politics  , theme : # , title : Mirror Politics ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true""Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email Theresa May won a late breakthrough in Strasbourg last night to convince MPs to back her Brexit deal.Parliament will vote at pm on the -page deal with the EU - some  days after it suffered the worst defeat in House of Commons history. Mrs May claims shes secured legally-binding changes that ensure we wont be trapped indefinitely in the backstop - a clause that could extend EU customs rules over the UK. But how does it compare to what she actually promised  Here is a quick guide.  Two things. Firstly, she promised a signicant and legally binding change to the Brexit deal itself - not, as shes presented today, some extra papers around it. Secondly. she said she would seek either a time limit, or a unilateral exit clause, or alternative arrangements to the Irish border backstop.On January , Theresa May told MPs: What I am talking about is not a further exchange of letters but a signicant and legally binding change to the withdrawal agreement.Negotiating such a change will not be easy. It will involve reopening the withdrawal agreement - a move for which I know there is limited appetite among our European partners. But I believe that with a mandate from this House... I can secure such a change in advance of our departure from the EU.  Three things: A legally-binding joint instrument which reflects a commitment to replace the backstop with alternative arrangements by December . The UK could go to an arbitration body to get permission to exit the backstopthat body agreed the EU was acting in bad faith to try and keep us in the backstop. A joint statement to go alongside the political declaration, which ministers say seeks to enhance and expedite the process of bringing the future relationship into force. A unilateral declaration on the temporary nature of the backstop, which will sit alongside the Withdrawal Agreement. This says that it is the UKs understanding thatthe EU doesnt keep up its end of the bargain in the future relationship negotiations, Britain can pull out of the backstop on its own.  Theresa May said her plan will involve reopening the withdrawal agreement. But she hasnt done that.Instead, she has secured three documents which are additional to the -page Brexit deal.Irish premier LeoVaradkarmade clear today that they did not reopen the withdrawal agreement or undermine the Irish border backstop. . A time limit on the backstop  She hasnt done it. Under the plans outlined last night, the Irish border backstop is not time limited. The deal commits both sides to work speedily on an agreement that supersedes the backstop by  December , but that is not a guarantee.  The deal does provide a way to exit the backstop. But its really long-winded, and only worksthe EU is deemed by an independent  to be intentionally showing bad faith. This is really hard to prove. Under the deal, both sides have agreed itll be a legal breachthey act with the objective of applying the backstop indefinitely. If the EU is doing this, the UK can seek a legally binding ruling that says so by an arbitration  under a dispute settlement mechanism.If the  agrees with Britain,and the EU continues to ignore the ruling persistently, then there might be something called temporary remedies. Onlyafterthat, ultimately, the aggrieved party would have the right to exit the backstop. We havent got these. Yet. Instead the deal commits both sides to try and find them before  December , which is when the backstop would kick in. The agreement says both sides commit to working speedily on a subsequent agreement that establishes by  December  alternative arrangements, so that the backstop will not need to be triggered. But thats not a guarantee. There would be a negotiating track to help this happen and a high level conference at least every six months. But thats simply not the same as a cast-iron pledge in law. And in Theresa Mays own words...  The Prime Ministers statement to Parliament today basically confesses her deal doesnt go far enough.She says itreduces the riskthe UK could be deliberately held in the Northern Ireland backstop indefinitely.That, you will notice, is not a guarantee. We can reduce the risk of England losing in the group stages of the next World Cup, but it doesnt mean theyll win - in the final.

title: voice mirror safety must come
story: NewsopinionVoice of the Mirror: Safety must come first with flights - so we must investigateThe public will rightly be concerned that British airlines are refusing to take Boeing  Max s out of service, after Sunday’s accident in Ethiopia and an earlier one off the coast of IndonesiaShareCommentsByVoice of the Mirror:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR NewsopinionPeople stand near collected debris at the crash site of Ethiopia Airlines near Bishoftu "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailGrounding Boeing  Max s for urgent safety checks is sensible after two new planes crashed within five months of each other, killing hundreds of people. The public will rightly be concerned that British airlines are refusing to take them out of service, after Sunday’s accident in Ethiopia and an earlier one off the coast of Indonesia. Safety should be paramount in the aviation industry, which is why international air accident investigators are anxious to discoverthe two crashes were a grim coincidence or evidence of a more widespread problem. We are not prejudging the inquiry’s outcome.   But when Ethiopia, Indonesia and China are among the nations grounding the jets, surely erring on the side of caution is the right choice. US manufacturer Boeing will have to co-operate fully and allow its performance records to be examined. It is better to be safe than sorry when it comes to people’s lives. Brexit caution Last throws of the dice are rarely as theatrical as Theresa May’s dash to Strasbourg for Brexit talks last night. She’s desperately searching for a solution that forces hardline Tories to start backing her bad deal. But our country will pay the price. The truth is that May’s poundbillion EU orce would be an expensive, avoidable disaster. MPs should hold their nerve, refuse to be panicked, reject her poor offering and vote for extra time to find an answer that is best for Britain.  A growing chorus of Tories are demanding that she quit, but May is prioritising her own position over the national interest. And that isn’t leadership – that’s putting herself first. Halt kne sales Stopping the sale of terrying “Rambo” knives – popular among some gang members – is a small but signicant step towards reducing street violence. We have consistently argued that there’s no single, simple answer to halting stabbings, but fewer weapons is surely part of the solution.

title: termination adoption keep three words
story: NewsTermination, adoption or keep - three words that taught me how precious my baby wasEXCLUSIVE: Jessica Egan, , is mum to little Gwendolyn, who was born with Downs Syndrome. Here, Jessica, from Utah, US, describes her devastation at her daughters diagnosis, before finding magic in her pregnancy again and marvelling at her wonderful baby girl...ShareCommentsByAbigail OLeary:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR NewsMy beautul baby girl was born in December "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailI didnt ask for extra chromosomes when I placed my order. Regular amount of chromosomes, please, I quietly requested. But then came the news my order was definitely in production and, get this - I was being given extra chromosomes, for free. I was mad, confused as to why I had been chosen for this totally unexpected, unrequested upgrade. But I decided receiving my order in a few months time was better than getting nothing at all. And then it arrived. Our sweet Gwendolyn entered our lives in December last year - and she had Downs Syndrome. They were right - the upgrade was so worth it. Extra cute, extra special, extra joy and extra chromosome.   I met Josh in January , and things moved pretty quickly. After getting married the following year, we knew we wanted a baby so started trying right away. But things werent really going to plan and after a year, we still had no luck -so we turned to IVF. Then came another blow. Our first attempt hadnt worked, but we were so desperate for this baby - we knew we had to try again. There was a lot of love and determination for it to happen. Eventually, our dreams came true and we were told I was pregnant in April last year. We were totally overjoyed - overwhelmed almost.   For the next week, I took around five or six pregnancy tests a day - just to prove to myself it was real. It seemed too good to be true. But with the joy, came worries that somehow the baby would be harmed. Would they survive  Is everything going OK  Will the next scan go well  You ask yourself a lot of questions. Despite our natural fretting, the next  weeks were magical. We were excited to meet this little person who was all ours. We never imagined our bundle of love would come packaged just a tiny bit dferent. The devastation hit four days after the -week blood test.   I was at work and a call from the doctor sent me flying from my desk - I couldnt even look or talk to my colleagues. The pain was immediate. Josh came home too, and we sat there in shared devastation at the news our baby would have a % chance of Downs Syndrome. Those first few days can only be described as a grieving process - we grieved for the baby we thought wed have and the magical pregnancy we had been enjoying. This happens to other people. How can this happen to me  were my honest feelings and thoughts at the time. It was an unreal time, but one I am glad to have experienced. After days of feeling hopelessly down, we started thinking back over the previous weeks, when we were giddy parents-to-be.   So we picked ourselves up and contacted our local Downs Syndrome foundation - who were a huge support. We were visited by people from the Downs Syndrome community and met some amazing and inspiring iniduals.I started to immerse myself in groups - from Facebook pages for support to local groups of expectant mums with the same diagnosis as my baby.While I was embracing this new path, I still found those next three months of pregnancy hard at times. I was sometimes afraid to talk to people about my bump and open up about my baby - I was worried Id get pitying looks or people wouldnt be as excited for me as they would other mums. But other than the ferocious love I already had for my baby, a glimmer of hope came in another, more unusual, form.  After the initial test, we were advised to go for a second, which would give a % accurate diagnosis. Josh and I decided this was the best option. We didnt want people telling us there was still a chance she would be fine and that it might not be right. We wanted to know exactly who our precious daughter was and doing so really helped us fall back in love with my pregnancy again. After the final test, which officially confirmed Gwendolyn had Downs Syndrome, we were handed three leafelts. Termination, Adoption and Keeping your Baby. It was a lot to take in, but something struck us. As we read the literature on adoption, we learned there was a huge waiting list for people wanting to adopt babies with Downs Syndome. People were actually waiting to adopt my baby - and it hit me how precious and valued these children really are.  The rest of the pregnancy was normal and we loved seeing her wriggle around on scans - we were desperate to meet her and hopelessly in love. At  weeks, doctors said my placenta wasnt ing so well - another common effect of the extra chromosome. We were told wed be meeting our little girl that very same day and I got booked in for an immediate C-section. The first sight of our little Gwendolyn was breathtaking - all lbs,  ounces, of her. She was tiny, but perfect. With her being a smaller and premature baby, we had to leave her in hospital for a week as nurses monitored her feeding before allowing us to take her home. Staying away from her was so hard, we eventually began staying at her side in the night.  In the days wed go to baby school, as we nicknamed it - where nurses and doctors told us how to feed her and care for any needs she may have. When we finally took her home, it was magical. We had the baby wed dreamed of for so long. The road to getting there hadnt been what we expected, but we had our sweet Gwendolyn to show for it. Today, Gwendolyn is a healthy and happy baby. But weve been told she may need surgery at six months old to help with a heart canal defect. Still, she doesnt let it bother her - she loves her food and shes so engaged and happy. Looking back at my journey to this point, I think it was important to grieve after first receiving the news about Gwendolyn.

story: NewsKate Middleton wears stunning Gucci violet as she visits childrens centre in LondonThe Duchess of Cambridge is at the Henry Fawcett Centre in southeast LondonShareCommentsByRussell Myers:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news uk-news video watch-duchess-cambridge-visits--,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news uk-news  , theme : # , title : Mirror UK News ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news uk-news  , theme : # , title : Mirror UK News ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true""Get the biggest Royal Family stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe Duchess of Cambridge is wearing a stunning violet Gucci blouse and trousers and personal fashion favourite Jigsaw as she visits a childrens centre in London. The royal is visiting the Henry Fawcett Childrens Centre in Lambeth, to learn about the work being done by local Lambeth organisations to support children and their families as she continues her focus on childrens wellbeing. In the Duchess first appearance since her show of unity with the Duchess of Sussex on Monday she wore Jigsaw trousers, in a nod to the fashion brand where she got her start as a buyer. Kate Middleton and Meghan Markle sparkled in a show of support for the Queen in their visit to Westminster Abbey for Commonwealth Day.  The pair joined the rest of the Royal Family for the service, on the day that celebrates Britains connections with Commonwealth countries. Meghan and Prince Harry , who are expecting their first child in a matter of weeks, arrived first. The Duchesses exchanged kisses on both cheeks as the Cambridges arrived at the service. Today will be another busy schedule of engagements for Kate, who is also due to rub shoulders with the art world elite at the  Portrait Gala at the National Portrait Gallery tonight.    At the childrens centre this morning she will be shown how the Lambeth Early Action Partnershipfor supporting stronger families works. LEAP is using a programme called the Parent and Infant Relationship Service. Lambeth is one of five locations around the UK where the programme is being piloted. EAP was set up, and all their work with families is funded by A Better Start, a major -year funding initiative from The National Lottery Community Fund.    The lottery fund has supported five locations across the UK, including Lambeth, to test new ways of making support services for families stronger. The visit continues The Duchess’s focus on Early Years. It comes shortly after The Duke and Duchess of Cambridge met with frontline service providers such as health visitors involved in delivering the Better Start programme during their visit to Blackpool. The Duchess will join parents and their toddlers taking part in sessions offered by LEAP and PAIRS, called ‘Circle of Security’ and ‘Together Time’, to see dferent examples of what is available as part of the programme. Circle of Security is one of two universal programmes that is offered to all parents with children of  to  years. It helps parents and care givers better understand their child’s emotions, as well as supporting their child’s ability to successfully manage their own emotions and enhance the development of their child’s self-esteem. Together Time supports attachment and bonding between parents and infants. The group provides time and space for parents to enjoy being with their babies or toddlers and includes singing, use of child-led play and interaction.  The session is designed to support parents’ ability to understand their child’s cues, feel more confident in their parenting and strengthen their relationship with their child. During her visit, The Duchess will meet with representatives from the dferent organisations working to support families in Lambeth. They include The National Lottery Community Fund, the National Children’s Bureau, which coordinates LEAP, and the South London and Maudsley NHS Foundation Trust , which has helped develop PAIRS.

story: NewsMadeleine McCann suspect seen carrying small girl is key to solving case, expert saysThe mystery man was spotted by an Irish family, the Smiths, on the night three-year-old Madeleine vanished in May ShareBySophie Evans:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR NewsMadeleine was just three when she vanished in Portugal in May  "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA man seen carrying a small girl dressed in pyjamas on the night Madeleine McCann vanished is key to solving the case, an expert claims.The mystery man was spotted by an Irish family, the Smiths, who were holidaying in Portugal at the same time as the McCanns in May . The family would later claim they saw him carrying a girl, wearing pink and white pyjamas, down a quiet street around m from the beach. And US criminal profiler Pat Brown believes the sighting is the key in Madeleines case, which has yet to be solved more than a decade on. This is the number one issue about the whole case, and Ive stuck by this for years, and I stand by it today, she told  News in a podcast. Madeleine was just three when she vanished from an apartment in Praia da Luz, where she had been sleeping with her twin siblings.   At the time, her parents Kate and Gerry were dining with pals nearby.The reported sighting by the Smiths was at around pm on May , . The same night, a friend of Kate and Gerry also reportedly saw a dark-haired man carrying a child away from the direction of the apartment.But this sighting, by Jane Tanner, was reported to be  minutes before the Smiths one and was in a dferent location, the news site reports. Jane claimed she had gone for a walk when she saw, in the darkness and from some distance, a man carrying a child across the road ahead.“What makes the Smith sighting very interesting is that Jane Tanner is a friend, and the Smith sighting is a bunch of people that have no clue who the McCanns are, Pat, from Washington DC, says in the Maddie podcast.   These are not their friends. She adds: I believe the Smith sighting occurred. I believe they saw a man carrying a little girl down that road, which is towards the beach. E-fits of a suspect, based on evidence from holidaymaker Martin Smith and his family, were unveiled years after Madeleines disappearance.Meanwhile, an artist drew an impression of the so-called Tannerman - the man spotted by Jane, who was considered a suspect for years. Pats comments are made in the third episode of the podcast, which looks into the high-profile case and the two sightings that night.According to  News, the criminal profiler has studied the case in exhaustive detail, even flying out to visit Praia da Luz itself. Madeleine would now be , turning  in May this year.In November , Operation Grange, the Met Police investigation into her disappearance, was given a further pound, from the Home Office. This provided funding up to March  this year. The podcast is hosted by Australian journalist Mark Saunokonoko. A Netflix documentary about the case is set to be broadcast next month. Kate and Gerry earlier released a statement about the Netflix show. They said: We are aware that Netflix are planning to screen a documentary in March  about Madeleine’s disappearance.  The production company told us that they were making the documentary and asked us to participate.We did not see and still do not see how this programme will help the search for Madeleine and, particularly given there is an active police investigation, could potentially hinder it. Consequently, our views and preferences are not reflected in the programme. We will not be making any further statements or giving interviews regarding this programme.

story: NewsMeghan Markle and Kate Middleton exchange kisses as they arrive at Commonwealth serviceMeghan Markle and Kate Middleton joined the rest of the Royal Family at Westminster Abbey for a service to celebration Commonwealth DayShareCommentsByZoe ForseyAudience WriterSophie Evans:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news uk-news video kate-kisses-meghan-cheek-touching-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news uk-news  , theme : # , title : Mirror UK News ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news uk-news  , theme : # , title : Mirror UK News ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true""Get the biggest Royal Family stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email The Duchesses of Cambridge and Sussex greeted each other with a kiss on both cheeks as they arrived at the Commonwealth Day service . story: NewsUK weather forecast: Storm Gareth ,-mile weather bomb to bring mph windsThe Met Office has issued severe weather warnings for most of the UK as the ,-mile wide "weather bomb" hitsShareCommentsByChris kitchingAlistair Grant:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news uk-news offline video weather-warnings-place-storm-gareth-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news uk-news  , theme : # , title : Mirror UK News ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news uk-news  , theme : # , title : Mirror UK News ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true""Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email Dangerous Storm Gareth is set to bring potentially destructive and le-threatening weather conditions that threaten widespread travel chaos and power cuts to most of the UK. The ,-mile wide weather bomb has triggered severe weather warnings from the Met Office with gales up to mph and heavy rain expected for more than  hours once the storm makes landfall.A yellow warning for strong winds covers Northern Ireland, Wales, most of England and western parts of Scotland, while a rain warning has been issued for the North West of England, where more than two inches could fall. Storm Gareth brings a risk of damage to buildings, flying debris, large waves and flooding in addition to power cuts and travel chaos, forecasters said. Showers could be wintry over hills while northern and central parts could be hit by thunderstorms and hail as the country is battered by the massive and powerful storm.   The intense storm, caused by a deep area of low pressure, has been given a name to bring greater urgency and awareness to the Met Offices warnings. Forecasters have urged people to take precautions so they arent caught out by severe weather. The Met Office has issued three separate weather warnings for wind or rain before the worst of Storm Gareth hits. The first covers the North West of England, where more than two inchesof rain could fall over higher ground in Cumbria by pm on Tuesday, increasing the risk of flooding on already wet ground.  About .insis expected quite widely. The second warning, for wind, covers Northern Ireland from pm Tuesday to pm Wednesday. The Met Office said: A spell of strong northwesterly winds are expected across Northern Ireland for the evening travel period, continuing overnight and Wednesday morning. Gusts of up to mph are likely inland with a small chance of reaching mph for a time in squally showers.  Gusts of -mph are likely along northern coasts, perhaps up to mph for a time. Winds will steadily ease through Wednesday morning. Those strong winds will later extend into Wales, England and Scotland, where a yellow warning will be in place from pm on Tuesday until pm on Wednesday. The Met Office warned: A spell of strong northwesterly winds is expected to develop across southwest Scotland late on Tuesday evening then extend across much of England and Wales through Wednesday.  Gusts of up to -mph are likely inland and mph along western coasts. Winds will gradually ease during Wednesday afternoon. Almost two dozen flood alerts have been issued across northern England. In Wales, four have been issued around Snowdonia National Park and two in Brecon Beacons National Park. Scotland has issued six flood warnings and two flood alerts.  On Tuesday morning, winds were already gusting to mph at Mumbles Head in South Wales, and mph at both St Marys on the Isles of Scilly and the South Ulst Range in northwest Scotland. By .am almost two inchesof rain had fallen at Capel Curig in North Wales over the previous  hours, while Shap in Cumbria had recorded a similar amount . A yellow weather warning for rain is also in place in parts of northern England on Thursday and Friday. Drivers have been told to expect longer journey times, while air, rail and bus passengers could face delays or cancellations.  Temperatures will hit about C in some places, but it wont feel pleasant due to the wind and or rain. Gareth is slamming in the UK just days after severe winds, snow and rain caused disruption on Sunday. Why Storm Gareth  The Met Office and Met Eireann, the Irish weather service, produce a list of storm names just before the beginning of autumn every year. Its believed that people pay closer attention to severe weather warningsit is a named storm. Gareth was named by Met Eireann and is the third named storm this year after Erik in February and Freya earlier this month. Gareth has been dubbed a ,-mile wide weather bomb, or explosive cyclogenesis, when air pressure drops rapidly in a single day.  The rotation of a storm is increased, creating destructive weather conditions. Storms Ali and Bronagh hit in September last year, Callum in October and Deirdre in December. The next named storms will be Hannah, Idris and Jane. Met Office five-day weather forecastTuesdayHeavy rain across Wales and northern England, spreading southeastwards, with gusty winds. Brighter skies following from the north and later west, with heavy, blustery showers, wintry over northern hills. Turning very windy later, with severe gales in the northwest. Tuesday nightVery windy with severe gales in the north. Heavy and squally showers across northern and central parts with risk of hail of thunder. Drier in the south with clear spells.WednesdayCold and very windy with sunshine and showers, heavy in places with snow over northern hills. Showers will steadily ease but rain will reach the west later.Thursday to SaturdayUnsettled throughout with bouts of wind and rain, heaviest in the west. Some drier and brighter interludes are likely. Rather cold in the north, milder at times in the south. Snow on the way The Met Offices extended forecast is predicting further spells of rain and snow as spring nears. The forecast, for Saturday  March to Monday  March, says: Cloud and rain are expected to affect the south, and perhaps central parts, of the UK early on Saturday, and will clear with bright and showery weather extending countrywide by the days end. Showers may be heavy in the north and fall as a mixture of sleet or snow, especially on high ground.Any strong winds will ease through the day too. Lighter winds and cooler on Sunday. Then there are signals for an Atlantic-driven and unsettled theme through the following week. We are likely to see further spells of wind and rain, followed by drier, more showery periods. The wettest, windiest weather always most likely in the northwest. Towards the end of the outlook there may be a tendency for more settled conditions to affect southern areas. The first day of spring is Wednesday  March.

But the love and attention he is getting now from Laurence is wonderful. Snoop is living like a king.   The video, released on Christmas Eve, shows the Staffordshire Bull Terrier led out of a car at the side of the road. story: NewsMum-to-be whose lunch kept getting stolen at work catches thief and has her firedDont mess with a hungry pregnant womanShareCommentsByBlathin De PaorZahra MulroySocial Audience Editor:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR NewsElizaconceived again VERY quickly "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email It doesnt matteryoure a CEO or an intern, having your food nicked from the fridge is an occupational hazard wherever you work .If youre lucky, this will only happen on a handful of occasions during your working le. Youll fume, perhaps resort to passive-aggressive labels, maybe even send a scathing email, but youll get over it. Imagineit happened to you every day, though For one mum-to-be this is exactly what was happening to her.Every day she took in a delicious homemade lunch created for her by her chef husband.Every day it got pinched from the fridge at work, RSVP Live reports.  She even explained that her husband would happily make the thief lunch, for a small fee. But while other colleagues took her up on this, the thief persisted. Then cameras were installed in the kitchen. She told Reddit: I began labelling my food hoping that would deter the thief. It didnt. Eventually, I put a note on the fridge that said: Please stop taking my food. I am pregnant and breastfeeding and this is negatively affecting my health.  The thief was a middle-aged woman who doesnt seem to like me. She is making triple what I am making,not more. After a week of thisI had the IT guy send me a screen-grab of her stealing, one from each day. Lunch Thief was up for a promotion. She’s near the executive level, and once you get this high up, the interviews involve execs from headquarters flying down to meet up with the execs in our office to sit in on presentations from the interviewees. The mum-to-be then admitted that she pinned up a photo of the lunch thief stealing her food.   Sheturned back to look at the screen in horror. The execs at my office who knew my lunches were getting stolen were visibly pissed at her. As it turns out, one of the execs who’d come from headquarters was also pregnant, and the other one had a we who’d just had a baby. She was terminated. It sounds cutthroat, but the woman reveals she never wanted it to go this far.  I didnt want her to get fired, I just wanted her to stop. Never even asked me to send them the picture evidence for their own record.

title: baby boy cooked inside hot
story: NewsBaby boy cooked inside hot car while parents got high on synthetic cannabisEight-month-old Isaiah Neil died from heatstroke after he was left strapped inside the car outside his grandparents home, prosecutors claimShareBySophie Evans:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR NewsLittle Isaiah Neil died from heatstroke after being left in a hot car for several hours, prosecutors claim "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA baby boy cooked inside a hot car for three hours while his parents were getting high on synthetic cannabis, a court has heard. Little Isaiah Neil died from heatstroke after he was left strapped inside the vehicle outside his grandparents home, prosecutors claim. The eight-month-old was said to be limp, sweaty and hot when he was discovered by his father, Shane Neil, in November . Neil would later tell a police officer: We cooked the baby. Worried about his son, the dad said he rushed him inside and woke up his partner Lacey Te Whetu - Isaiahs mum - who had fallen asleep. Giving evidence in court, Neil said Te Whetu checked on Isaiah and found him to be fine and breathing, so the youngster was put to bed.But at around pm, he said he woke up and checked on the baby again at the property in Ruatoki, New Zealand, according to local media.   The child was saturated with sweat - and despite efforts to cool him down and revive him, he sadly died, the New Zealand Herald reports. While the Crown says he died from heatstroke, the defence has rejected this, saying there is considerable doubt it caused his death. Neil and Te Whetu have both pleaded guilty to manslaughter after their little boy died at the scene near Whakatāne, jurors have heard. They are now witnesses in the trial of Te Whetus mum Donna Catherine Parangi - who is charged with grandson Isaiahs manslaughter. Parangi has pleaded not guilty to the charge. The court has heard that the trio all lived together and were smoking synthetic cannabis on the day Isaiah died, according to the Herald. They all fell asleep, leaving the baby in the vehicle, prosecutors say. Under questioning from Richard Marchant, prosecuting, Neil said that he had found his son inside the car, with all the windows closed. [He was] sweaty, wet, hot, said the father. He added that he took the youngster inside and checked him for a pulse, but said: I couldnt tell, I was still pretty high.   The court heard Neil then woke up Te Whetu, who said Isaiah was still breathing, so the parents both went back to bed. But Neil said he later discovered the unresponsive infant in his cot. In a panic, he and Te Whetu sprinkled cold water on their son and gave him CPR, before paramedics tried to resuscitate the youngster. Te Whetu was said to be screaming and out of control. Tragically, Isaiah couldnt be saved. Neil told the court that he was gone. The court heard a pathologist found extensive bruising and an adult bite mark on the babys body following his death. Giving evidence, Neil denied inflicting the injuries. Parangis defence lawyer, Susan Gray, hit out at some of the fathers evidence, saying it was a figment of his imagination. Gray has said science is not on the side of the Crown in this case and that asphysxia could be another possible cause of Isaiahs death. Following Neils evidence, Te Whetu appeared as a witness and told jurors that her mum, who was working full-time, helped her to look after Isaiah because she wasnt capable herself. The court heard Te Whetu had a drug addiction, Newstalk ZB reports. The mother told jurors that her son felt hot when he was recovered from the car, but she thought he had been in a deep sleep. The trial at the High Courtat Hamilton continues.

story: NewsBoy, , writes incredibly sweet letter to airline CEO - and gets the best replyA -year-old boy who loves planes sent a brilliant letter to the CEO of Qantas Airlines and was surprised when he got a responseShareCommentsByCourtney PochinAudience Writer:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR NewsAlex Jacquot wants to run his own Airline one day "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailMark our words, Alex Jacquot will be flying high one day as CEO of his own Airline, called Oceania Express.The adorable -year-old boy from Australia has gone viral on social media after writing a letter to Alan Joyce the CEO of Qantas.In his handwritten note, Alex asks Alan to please take [him] seriously before launching into a discussion about his future business plans - and asking for some advice on how he can get his own company up and running.  In a post on Twitter , Qantas shared the full letter and revealed that Alan had taken the time to reply, CEO to CEO.They tweeted: Our competitors dont normally ask us for advice, but when an airline leader reached out, we couldnt ignore it. Naturally, there was only one way to respond: CEO to CEO. The tweet quickly garnered a lot of attention, with over , retweets and more than , likes.   Alexs letter reads: Dear Mr Alan Joyce AC,Im Alex Jacquot, a -year-old boyand I want to start an airline. I have already started some suff, like what type of planes Ill need, flight numbers, catering and more.Im the CEO of the airline, which by the way is called Oceania Express. Ive also hired a CFO, a Head of IT, a Head of Maintenance, a Head of On Board Services and a Head of Legal as well, along with my friend Wolfwe are both co-founders. Number two: Do you have any tips on starting an airline  Id be very grateful to know what youd have to say. Number three: Im thinking about, as you are, about an A for Sydney Melbourne to London flights. Seeing as it is a  hour flight, we are having a lot of trouble thinking about sleep. Do you have any advice    Hope to hear from you soon! Yours sincerely, Alex Jacquot, CEO and Co-Founder of Oceania Express. Mr Joyce replied to the letter, thanking the youngster for letting him know about his new airline and said hed heard rumours of another entrant in the market. He then went on to offer some advice, even though hes not in the business of confiding in his competitiors. He said: My number one tip for starting an airline is to put safety front and centre.
