Now to your troubles thinking about sleep on -hour flights. This is something we are grappling with too, as we embark on Project Sunrise . To help with sleep, were looking at dferent cabin designs that give people spaces to stretch out and exercise. Mr Joyce went on to invite Alex to a very special Projecct Sunrise meeting to compare notes on what its like to run an airline, and offered to give him a tour of the Operations Centre, where they keep an eye on every flight around the world.

title: catherine shaw brit backpacker possibly
story: NewsBrit backpacker Catherine Shaw possibly murdered after naked body found in GuatemalaCatherine Shaw, from Witney, Oxfordshire, was last seen leaving the Eco Hotel Mayachik carrying a stray puppyShareCommentsByGerard CouzensChris kitching:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR NewsCatherine Shaw, , was found dead after failing toto her hotel in Guatemala "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe death of a British backpacker whose naked body was found on a mountainside in Guatemala is being investigated as a possible murder. Catherine Shaws body was discovered on Monday, a week after she was last seen leaving a hostel carrying a stray puppy. It is believed the -year-old, from Witney, Oxfordshire, had hiked from Eco Hotel Mayachik to the Nariz del Indio summit, overlooking Lake Atitlan, to watch the sunrise on March . After the search came to a tragic end, a preliminary police report claimed the Brit was found naked and had visible blows to her body and lacerations on her left leg. Her father had reportedly flown to the Central American country to join the search.   Miss Shaws jacket and trousers were found on the mountain shortly before her body was discovered near the village of San Juan La Laguna. Her body was found about ft from where the puppy was found on Friday, said Amy Farrow, an American woman involved in the search for Miss Shaw. Community leader Juan Mendoza said the trousers had been found at the Nariz del Indio summit. Mr Mendoza described the -year-old’s death as a crime and called on authorities to find those responsible. Police sources told local press they believed she had been murdered, although officially Guatemala’s PNC force said only it had launched a “criminal investigation” into the “deplorable incident.”  Miss Shaw was found naked near a popular mountain beauty spot called Nariz del Indio - Indian Nose in English - which is a two-hour hike from the hotel she was staying at and is regularly visited by backpackers who travel to the spot nearly ,ft above sea level to watch the sun come up. The peak of the mountain, where a lookout shack with wooden benches has been built which visitors can climb on top of to enjoy a panoramic view of Lake Atitlan, is the tip of the Indian nose and was considered a sacred site by the Mayans who would pray and conduct religious services. Mr Mendoza, revealing volunteers had found Miss Shaw’s body and another search team had found a pair of trousers believed to be the backpacker’s, said: “It’s terrible this type of thing happens in our area and we urge the authorities to investigate because these crimes stain the good name of our municipality.”  A preliminary police report, leaked to local press, said Miss Shaw was found “totally naked, face down and at first sight has visible blows to her body and lacerations on her left leg. A spokesman for Guatemala’s PNC police confirmed she had “several blows” but said the state of decomposition of her body meant it was not possible to confirm how the injuries had been caused at the scene of the find, and forensic experts would have to determine the cause of death. Guatemala’s Interior Ministry said in a statement after Miss Shaw’s body was found: “After several days of intense searching by police authorities, other institutions and volunteers for the missing British national, participating teams are being coordinated at the scene where her body has been found. “After  hours of an exhaustive search, the result is very regrettable and the Interior Ministry and police chiefs have immediately designated a team which will carry out the criminal investigation.  “This is to determine what has happened and who could be involved in this deplorable incident. Ms Farrow, who lives in the town where Miss Shaw was staying, said the body has been recovered by local authorities. She wrote on Facebook: “We are deeply saddened that it turned into a body recovery mission instead of a rescue.“When we set out to help find her we were hopeful to locate her alive.” She said teams of volunteers, local authorities, a helicopter, drones and search dogs were involved in the effort.  Ms Farrow wrote: “As horrible as it was, we were also relieved to at least know where she was. She was about  feet down from where reports of the puppy was found . She added: “Once the autopsy is conducted, we can determineit was a fall or foul play.“Given how concerned the locals and towns are it was very apparent this incident is pretty rare in beautul #lagoatitlan.” Miss Shaw disappeared in the early hours of March  after leaving Eco Hotel Mayachik clutching a puppy and leaving her mobile phone and passport behind in her room. The stray dog - shivering but alive - was found at the highest lookout of Indian Nose, near to the spot where her body was found, between am and am on Friday morning.  Ms Farrow wrote: We knew from friends that a nature lover spirit like Catherine would not have left the small dog alone. Miss Shaws distinctive woollen pink and cream jacket was found at the base of the hike and handed to police, and her trousers were later found at the summit. Her had been travelling in Guatemala for two weeks, having previously been in Mexico and Calornia, before she disappeared. She was travelling with a friend, who woke up on the morning of March  to find that she was missing. Before Miss Shaws body was found, her parents, Ann and Tarquin Shaw, had said they were desperately worried and her disappearance was unusually.  They said in a statement: She has always been really good about keeping in touch and informing us of her whereabouts and activities. So this is unusual behaviour which gives us great concern for her safety. Please help us to find her. The Lucie Blackman Trust, which is supporting Ms Shaws family, said on Monday evening that a body had been found which is believed to be Ms Shaws. In a statement it added: The Lucie Blackman Trust is saddened to announce that a body has been found in the search for Catherine Shaw. Formal identication has not taken place but the body is believed to be Catherine. Catherines family have been informed. Please respect their privacy at this dficult time. The charity said Ms Shaw had left the hotel in Mayachik, near San Pedro and San Juan, on March  at .am, but then ed at .am.  She then left again for the last time at .am, heading in the direction of the lake. The trust said that at this point she had a puppy with her but no other possessions. A hand drum, known as a hang, previously reported to be in Ms Shaws possession, was left behind and has been located, and she did not have a guitar with her when she left, the trust added. The search encountered many challenges including communication issues due to lack of power in the area. Friends had set up a Facebook page to help to coordinate the search efforts and raise funds to pay for a helicopter to join the hunt for her. A post on Monday evening read: Our diligent searchers have found Catherine Shaw’s body at the top of El Naudiz in San Juan La Laguna. The municipality, police, rescuers and volunteers have been searching the area since :am this morning. We appreciate everyone’s effort and help in bringing resolution to the situation. This is all the information we have at this time.

title: how know your flight boeing
story: NewsHow to knowYOUR flight is a Boeing  Max The Ethiopian Airlines crash has raised safety concerns and left passengers wondering which airlines use the Boeing  Max ShareCommentsByChris kitching:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news video ethiopia-airlines-crash-wreckage-flight-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, combinedPrompt :true, subsets :[,,,,,],bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, combinedPrompt :true, subsets :[,,,,,],bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true""Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe Ethiopian Airlines disaster has sparked fresh safety questions about the Boeing  Max  passenger jet, which has been involved in two deadly crashes in five months. Everyone on board the new plane -  passengers and eight crew members - was killed when it went down just six minutes after taking off from Addis Ababa on Sunday morning. The cause of the crash isnt known, but in the aftermath of the tragedy Boeing model has been grounded by a number of countries and airlines until they are confident it is airworthy. Aviation experts have raised concerns and passengers are refusing to board the aircraft - but how do you knowyour upcoming flight uses a Boeing  Max     It is rather easy to find out through the airline itself or an aviation website or app. Check with your airline When you do an online search for flights it will usually tell you the flight number and possibly the type of plane that is scheduled to be used. If the search or booking process doesnt list the aircraft model, get in touch with the airline by phone or the internet to ask what plane is used one that route, or check an aviation tracking website or app.  If you have already booked a trip and you dont know what kind of aircraft is being used, you can find out by accessing your booking on the airlines website using your booking reference. It should list of the plane you will fly on. Check a plane tracking website Websites and apps that track planes will likely list the information you are looking for, but sometimes only in cases where flights are a few days or weeks away. Flightradar and FlightAware are two of the more popular sites which track planes in real-time and also have details about past and future journeys. You will need the flight number to find out which plane or planes are typically used on a certain route. For example, FlightAwares activity log for flight ET, the identier used by the plane that crashed, states that a Boeing - Dreamliner was used on the Addis Ababa-Nairobi route on Saturday, and a Boeing  Max  on Sunday. Check the planes registration  If you know the planes registration number you can look up details, including the type of plane and how old it is, on a public database run by a civil aviation body. You can find the registration number on the side of the plane or by looking up a specic flight on a tracking website or app. In the UK, passengers can check the Civil Aviation Authoritys website. Which airlines have stopped using the jet  Airlines such as Tui are continuing to operate flights out of the UK using Boeings  Max  plane despite suspensions around the world. Two Max  planes have crashed in five months - the Ethiopian Airlines aircraft and a Lion Air jet that went down in the Java Sea off Indonesia in October, killing everyone on board. Australia, Singapore and China have temporarily grounded the aircraft.  A number of airlines have grounded their fleet, including Royal Air Maroc, Cayman Airways, South Koreas Eastar Jet, Singapores SilkAir, Mongolian Airlines, Aeromexico, Aeroliacuteneas Argentinas and Comair, a British Airways franchise in southern Africa. Tui Airways has the only five  Max  aircraft operated by a UK-based airline, and is due to begin flying a sixth later this week. A spokesman for Tui said: We have no indication that we cant operate our  Max in a safe way like we do with all other planes in our network. Scandinavian airline Norwegian has  Boeing  Max  aircraft and continues to use the model. The airline said it is monitoring the Ethiopia case and will follow any recommendations from Boeing and civil aviation authorities. Ryanair, which is pressing ahead with an order for  of the jets, said it is also monitoring the situation. American Airlines, Southwest, Icelandair, Flydubai, WestJet, Air Canada and GOL Linhas Aereas also continue to use the plane. A quick search of Twitter shows passengers have expressed fears about boarding a Boeing  Max , with many tweets sent directly to airlines, asking themtheir upcoming flight uses one. What is Boeing saying  The US Federal Aviation Administration, which esponsible for certying all Boeing  Max  models, has told airlines it believes the aircraft to be airworthy. Chicago-based Boeing said it was working closely with the FAA on development, planning and certication of a software enhancement. The update is due to be rolled out in the coming weeks. Boeing has sent a team to the crash site in Ethiopia. Earlier, it said the investigation is in its early stages and there is no need to issue new guidance to operators of its  Max  aircraft.

title: double boost for dundee united as butcher and sow set to return
story: Dundee United are to receive a double boost for today’s Championship trip to take on struggling Partick Thistle.Midfielder Calum Butcher s from his one-game cup suspension, served last Sunday, while striker Osman Sow is in line to get a place on the bench after injury.Butcher’sshould add some steel to the Tangerines engine-room as they look to get the better of the bottom-placed Jags in Glasgow and, hopefully, close the gap on league leaders Ross County.Swedish hitman Sow has recovered from a calf problem and may be risked at some point this afternoon as United look to find the back of the net from open play after a deluge of penalty-kick goals in recent weeks.Terrors manager Robbie Neilson was delighted to have some key men back and available to choose from.“Butcher’s back in, which is great,” he said.“He brings that experience and that physicality so I’m pleased to bring him in.“Sow is fit. He has trained and will be involved today.“He had a wee calf problem which tightened up last Thursday.“We tried him on the Friday and he just didn’t think it was right, so we felt that it was better just to leave him out of it as opposed to putting him on the bench – bringing him on for  minutes and it blows up after .“I just felt last Sunday wasn’t the right one to put him in but he’ll be available today.“He’s a top player. I knew when I got him that it was going to take a bit of time to build him up and slowly get him where he is but he’s here for a period and there’s no doubt he’s got ability.“It’s just getting him on the pitch and getting him as fit as we can as quickly as we can without injuring him.”And Robbie hopes the -year-old’scan spur United on in the final third in their quest to come away from Maryhill with all three points.Expressing his disappointment about the lack of goals scored lately, he said: “We’ve not scored as many as we would like but when you look at the previous game at home, in the first  minutes, we had four or five chances to put the ball in the net and we didn’t do it.“It will come, we’re creating chances and just maybe not taking them but the most important thing is that you create.”

title: dundee girl says charity could have saved her mum who overdosed at 36
story: A Dundee teen has admitted her mum could have avoided dying from a drugs overdose at just she had sought help from local services.Alana Gowans, , lost her mum Alexis Watson to drugs in September last year, with the pain of the loss still fresh for the college student.But now Alana, who studies early childcare education at Dundee  Angus College, hopes to make a dference after winning a sum of cash to donate to a local charity.The city centre resident had a dficult upbringing as her mum lived a chaotic lestyle, meaning she had to move in with her gran aged just three.Alana said: “It was dferent, but gave me protection from seeing the substance use.“I was quite upset and angry and took it out on my gran sometimes.“My mum had been addicted to heroin since she was  and came off it for so long, but then she started to take Valium and sleeping tablets.“She wanted to get better for me, but it was hard.”Alana recognised there were many other young people across the city going through a similar experience.She said: “I’d say to anyone who is going through a dficult situation to go to the charity Addaction.“Every day is dferent. Some days I blame myself, but she’s in a better place.”Alana, along with fellow students from Gardyne Campus, won a grant for £, after completing a presentation on their chosen charity – Addaction – in front of a  from the Youth and Philanthropy Initiative.The team presented a cheque for the cash during a ceremony at the Addaction centre in Whitfield, while a tree will also be planted in memory of Alexis.Alana, who is hoping to become a nursery teacher after her studies, said: “We had to go to the charity and find out all the information and do a presentation in front of judges.“We didn’t know much about Addaction but last year I realised the support they give.“I think Addaction could have saved my mum.”Dave Barrie, service manager for Addaction, said: “It’s sad but it’s the reality.“It was heartbreaking to hear about. Having that loss is enormous for anyone.“The money will be going towards really good recovery programmes and we’re planting a tree in memory of her mum.”

title: dundee need to pick up points at home says jim mcintyre
story: Home matches against Hearts are where Dundee need to be picking up points, according to manager Jim McIntyre.The Dens boss felt his side were worth at least a point from Saturday’s - defeat to the Jambos but he concedes “it’s about making sure you are good in both boxes and we weren’t”.There were positives in the performance for the Dark Blues boss as his side created decent opportunities but conceded a poor th-minute winner from Sean Clare.Jim said: “It’s hard to be critical because it’s so scrappy.“It’s not asthey’ve cut us open.“Where I’m disappointed is that we don’t stop the cross but we have men in place and it is an old-fashioned stramash where the ball is stuck between bodies.“They got a toe-poke to it and it was a really frustrating goal, a scrappy, poor goal to give away.”Asked about the chances in the opening minutes of the game, Jim replied: “They are the opportunities you have to take.“Goals give you a real surge in belief but we are showing plenty of spirit because we are conceding the first goal a lot but we are coming back and still at it in the th minute.“At the same time, we are at home and we need to be picking up points against Hearts at Dens.“We had a brilliant result against them at Tynecastle but we want to be picking them up here and I felt there was enough in the performance to deserve at least a point.“It’s about making sure you are good in both boxes and we weren’t.”

title: ewan gurr this is why dundee council leader john alexander deserves credit after difficult period
story: Councillor John Alexander, the leader of Dundee City Council, has had a dficult month following ongoing criticism and protests over local budget cuts.However, I was impressed to discover the role he and his administration played in enabling Dundee to make a stand as the UK’s first living wage city.Our elected politicians deserve credit when they get it right and, on this, I believe they have.However, it has been a collective effort.Backed by Living Wage Scotland and Poverty Alliance, a cohort of  local employers including Dundee City Council, DC Thomson and Xplore Dundee have voluntarily committed to an action plan that ensures all their staff receive a real living wage of at least £ per hour, above the legal requirement of £., as well as encouraging other local employers to commit to doing likewise.The announcement took place in the vista room at the top of the DC Thomson building, with a panoramic view of Dundee in the background.Addressing a packed room, Mr Alexander said: “Living wage accreditation is not the only tool we have to overcome poverty, but it is one mechanism.”He later added: “This is as much about social, as well as physical, regeneration and having pride and confidence in your city.”

title: trade union seeks urgent meeting with dundee council over shift patterns
story: Trade union leaders representing Dundee care workers are seeking an urgent meetings about the latest proposals for sht patterns.Dundee City Council has written to Dundee Health and Social Care Partnership regarding “signicant progress” in the review of home care services.Helen Meldrum of the GMB, which represents hundreds of city council care workers, said the union was “cautious” about the announcement and needed more details.Ms Meldrum said: “We have yet to see any details.“There are no guarantees about whether our home care members will be required to change their hours of work or accept a huge pay cut which was part of the latest proposals to slash their terms and conditions.“We are seeking an urgent meeting with the council to discuss the detail of what this actually means.”A council spokesman said: “The letter from health and social care partnership chief officer David Lynch explains that, due to developments in the service, new sht plans will allow employees to remain on their existing work patterns.“They will not be asked to move to a split-sht system unless they have requested this change themselves.“The review of home care services considered sht patterns and models of delivery of the care at home services.“It looked to strike a balance between the expectations of our valued workforce and the needs of service users, now and in the future.“A lot has changed since the review was started.“There has been progress on the remodelling of pathways to support people being discharged from hospital, along with remodelling around primary care and community services, and the development of integrated roles.”

title: Bags of help at North Kessock beach clean
story: A MAJOR Black Isle beach clean against the backdrop of one of the peninsularsquos most recognisable landmarks recovered  bags of waste, among it syringes, plastic and fishing lines.It is the fth time a group led by Greenpeace volunteers from Inverness has cleaned the beach at Scarabs at North Kessock near the Kessock Bridge.Greenpeace activists ldquoadopted the beach via the Marine Conservation Society with the idea of not only cleaning up on a regular basis, but also monitoring results over a longer period.David Smith, of Greenpeace Inverness, said: ldquoWe had a great turn-out which I think was due to online shares, it was really good to have so many people along.The community beach clean attracted around  volunteers, among them Highland Green MSP John Finnie.Mr Finnie said: ldquoIt was a very successful day. It seemed to be very well attended which was great as it felt like we were all part of a community effort.Mr Finnie went on to say that although these litter clean-ups were essential, the long-term goal should be to stop littering altogether: ldquoIdeally we want a situation where people are not dropping any litter. Prevention is better than cure.Among the litter picked up from the popular recreational area were six used syringes which Mr Smith believes were washed up rather than dumped there.A spokesman for Highland Council said: ldquoMost pharmacies offer a free needle disposal service. Failing that, people can put them in a safe container and take them to out to the waste management team at Lotland Street. Discarded needles should not be taken to recycling centres as they are classed as special waste.Greenpeace Inverness was established in October  and has supported the organisationrsquos national and global campaigns.Tuesday  Mar  : AM

title: Campaigners press on with vision for Inverness park
story: CAMPAIGNERS hoping to transform a historic Inverness park into a vibrant green space are pressing on with their vision, despite suffering a setback.The Northern Meeting Park Group hopes to its application for a pound, grant to prepare a business plan and carry out surveys has been turned down by the Scottish Land Fund.Following feedback, however, it is now preparing to submit another application in May and is hoping for more positive news.It is also planning to open the usually locked park gates to the public for one week at Easter and another week in the school summer holidays.It lunches.Leading campaigner Jon Ford hopes to encourage greater use and activities during the opening weeks taking place April ndash and July ndash.ldquoThis year, we also want people to let us .In addition, discussions have taken place with the Calman Trust a young peoplersquos service offering housing support, training, employment opportunities, cooking services, about serving title: High Life Highland boss retires
story: The chief executive of High Le Highland , the biggest leisure services provider in the region, has announced his intention to retire from the top job in the summer.Ian Murray has been the boss of the charity since it was created by Highland Council in October  when it was tasked with delivering and developing the local authorityrsquos culture, learning, sport, leisure and health and well-being services.Since then it has grown to employ more than  full and part-time staff and support more than  volunteers with an annual turnover of pound million.Mr Murray first moved to the Highlands  years ago to take up the position of depute director of leisure services with what was then Ross and Cromarty District Council.When Highland Council was formed in  he moved to the region-wide remit of head of community learning and leisure before leading the transition of those services to High Le Highland seven years ago.Mr Murray said: ldquoLeading the transition to High Le Highland and the seven years since has been the most challenging, rewarding and enjoyable period in my career.ldquoSince HLH began, visitor numbers have grown almost three fold, annual income has doubled, reliance on council funding reduced by half and HLH has been asked by the council and several community groups to adopt  additional services, from the formerly community-run pools in Bettyhill and Poolewe to more recently the councilrsquos school music tutor service.ldquoI have been very fortunate to have been supported throughout by a very motivated, professional and innovative team across everything we do.HLH was recently the centre of tensions over funding as Highland Council drew up its budget and sought to make cuts that saw the price of HLH membership rise by around pound. In draft budget papers, a move to increase the revenue target by pound. million was tabled but later removed.Tuesday  Mar  : AM

story: MUSIC lovers enjoyed a host of outstanding performances at the latest outing for an event showcasing young Highland talent.This yearrsquos Inverness Music Festival concluded on Wednesday with the grand finale Premier Competition.Chairwoman Jean Slater said the musical skill on show this year had been exceptional.ldquoWersquove had an excellent standard of talent, she said. ldquoI know the adjudicators are very pleased with the standards which are taught in Highland schools.Dozens of young musicians from across the region won prizes, including Cannich Bridge Primary School which won the primary choir competition and Cradlehall Primary which won the preformed song category.Another exceptional talent was Alexander Scott-Brown , from Inverness, who won the festivalrsquos ultimate prize, the Curtis Craig Memorial Trophy, for the second year running.He won for an outstanding cello performance that had already seen him clock up a perfect  per cent score in the earlier open strings title: Inverness West residents asked to give their views
story: People living in the Inverness West ward of Highland Council are being invited to take part in two consultation events focussing on the main objectives for the area.Feedback from a similar event last year will be provided and members of the community will be able to see what progress has been made on a range of priorities.Residentsrsquo views on the Riverside Way project, progress with pedestrian crossings over the A, parking and the forthcoming West Link Phase  are very welcome as are any other areas of interest in the ward.In addition there will be drawings and further information on the West Link Phase , with staff available to answer questions.Councillor Graham Ross said: ldquoWe had a great response last year to our ward priority list and members of the community engaged very constructively in telling us about dferent issues and concerns, and suggesting how problems can be tackled."We look forward to sharing the progress made and to hearing of any fresh priorities for the ward. I would encourage as many people as possible to take up this chance to get involved and come along to either of the sessions.Both drop-in sessions will take place on Wednesday, March .The first is from pm to pm at the Bught Stop and the next is from pm-pm in Charleston Academy.Tuesday  Mar  : AM

title: My Ness art is approved
story: Three residents and Balleary Community Council failed to meet the deadline, although the planners did consider the community councilrsquos objection despite it being late.The artwork, My Ness, was approved under delegated powers, much to the surprise of some city councillors. Delegated powers meant that the application, from Highland Council, was considered by officials and not elected councillors.My Ness is a curved wall sweeping up and over the water which can be used as a seat, a walkway or a viewing .The concerns of the community council and the three iniduals included the impact on wildle and habitats, the deep piling required and possible pollution during construction.Cllr Ken Gowans said: ldquoThis is very disappointing as there are many unanswered questions that that could have been addressed at the planning committee. There are still concerns regarding the future of the fishermanrsquos hut, erosion of the river bank and where the displaced water will go in high water conditions.Cllr Bill Boyd said some people were not behind My Ness, which was to replace the highly controversial tilting pier artwork earmarked for the riverbank at Eden Court until it was ditched two years ago after a public furore. He said there was a question mark over the future of Inverness Angling Clubrsquos hut currently on the site.Zosia Fraser, chairwoman of Balleary Community Council, said: ldquoI think the fair and democratic way of dealing with this would be in open debate.Tuesday  Mar  : AM

title: New viewing platforms for Inverness riverside
story: A NEW series of "people perches" are to be installed along the River Ness to let people "engage" with the water ndash as a row continues over how plans for a more major piece of waterside art were approved.An artistrsquos impression shows the Rest Space to be sited in Bank Street, opposite the Mercure Hotel, as a set of steps leading to a fenced  over the river.One of several planned for theof the water it is currently in storage, with plans for its installation next month.Designed by Glasgow-based design practice Dress for the Weather it says on its website: "Rest Spaces is one of a series of art initiatives to encourage people to experience and engage with the river as it flows through the city.ldquoIt will encourage people to stop and enjoy the river in a iety of ways: to perch, to explore, to bask, to gather."Councillor Isabelle MacKenzie, chairwoman of the city of Inverness arts working group, which is overseeing the wide-ranging public art programme of which Rest Spaces is one part, said she thought it was ldquorather magnicent.Adding that, cumulatively, the artworks being created along the riverside would make walking in the area a more interesting experience she said: "There might well be some detractors but we are all iniduals."Councillor Ken Gowans, who was a vocal critic of the previous "tilting pier" proposals shelved several years ago, said he was more relaxed about the Bank Street installation."It will be in a very busy and popular location, especially with tourists, and I suspect it will add some interest to that part of the river," he said.Their remarks were made as other councillors continued to voice anger over revelations that the larger scale curving walls artwork proposed for a site close to the Ness Islands has been nodded through by planning officers rather than being put before elected members.Previously called The Gathering Place and My Ness, but referred to as My River Ness in the recently approved application, this artwork involves two crescent-shaped walls curving out from opposite sides of the river.Having been approved by officers under delegated powers councillors have reportedly been told there is now no way to call it in to the planning committeeNess-side SNP councillor Ron MacWilliam said he is set to meet with Inverness city centre manager David Haas over the issue and has called for a special meeting of the city of Inverness area committee."The natural urban environment is a key asset for Inverness and shouldnrsquot be degraded by development where it can be avoided," he said."The commitment by the previous council to spend on the original Gathering Place design, whilst not to everyonersquos pleasure, was based on an economic impact assessment which has never been revised to reflect the new location and design."Common sense tells you that not a soul will visit Inverness to view this utterly boring creation."He added: "As things stand it appears that as a member of the Inverness city committee, a trustee of the Inverness common good fund and member of the south planning applications committee I, and therefore the people I am elected to represent, have not been involved in the decision-making."Inverness West councillor Bill Boyd, who also sits on the planning committee, said he has written to officers to complain about the way the application has been dealt with.However Councillor Graham Ross, depute provost for Inverness, said it was his understanding that the application had been advertised following normal procedures and had failed to attract enough objections to require it to go to committee."The decision to approve was then taken under delegated powers, which means it met with all the planning regulations," he said.Tuesday  Mar  : AM

title: Second term for Inverness tourism business improvement district
story: Businesses have voted in favour of the Visit Inverness Loch Ness Tourism Business Improvement Districtcontinuing for a second term and a further five years, up to March , .Ballot papers were issued in January to  eligible voters and the count was held today with the result declared at Eden Court. businesses voted lsquoYesrsquo against  businesses which voted lsquoNorsquo.The BID area covers the Highland Council wards of Aird and Loch Ness, Inverness West, Inverness CentralInverness Ness-side, Inverness Millburn, Culloden and Ardersier and Inverness South.Tuesday  Mar  : AM

title: Smoking not wanted at Invernesss Victorian Market
story: Smokers could soon be made unwelcome around the entrances to Invernessrsquos historic Victorian Market as part of a drive to smarten up the appearance of the shopping arcade.The market itself is officially a smoke-free zone, but two letters sent out to traders asking them not to light up around the entrances have had no effect, it was reported at a meeting of the tradersrsquo association recently.Now market manager Jo Murray is investigating whether it would be legal for the smoking bins currently placed at the entrances to be removed in the hope that this will discourage smokers from congregating there.The meeting heard that among the smoking ldquoculprits at the Church Street entrance to the market are patrons of the neighbouring Market Bar, which shares an access close with the Victorian Market.Mrs Murray admitted: ldquoUnfortunately nothing can be done at the Market Bar entrance as it is private.ldquoHowever, I am checking with the fire service to ensure there is no legislation preventing the fire bins at other entrances being removed.ldquoDropped cigarette butts might become a problemthere are no bins, but litter wardens can fine offenders.The tradersrsquo association meeting agreed that removing the smoke bins at the entrances might help improve the image of the market.It was also agreed that all future Victorian Market literature will also declare it a smoke-free zone.Tuesday  Mar  : AM

title: boss denies reds best chance gone
story: Dons boss Derek McInnes has dismissed the doubters who believe they have missed their best chance of progressing in the Scottish Cup.Tonight Aberdeen play Rangers at Ibrox in their quarter-final replay for the right to face Celtic in the last four of the tournament.The replay occurs after a - draw at Pittodrie last Sunday week.The Reds dominated that encounter but were unable to claim victory. As a result plenty of pundits are making the Gers favourites to progress on their own patch this evening.However, McInnes insists nothing has changed as Aberdeen look to move a step closer to winning the Scottish Cup for the first time since .The Dons gaffer said: “The Scottish Cup is important and over the history of the club we haven’t won it as many times as we would have liked.“As a club we have not won it for a long time. In my time here we have been close.“We have reached semi-finals and a final but for us to achieve what we set out to do we will have to beat a strong Rangers in Glasgow.“The intention is to win the cup and nothing has changed just because we got a really dficult draw against Rangers.“People think we have missed our chance by being the better team at Pittodrie and not winning.“Just because the game is in Glasgow nothing has changed for us.“It will be two good teams going head to head and our intention is to put Rangers out and get through.“I want to win the Scottish Cup – but I don’t get too dispirited when we don’t.“The intention is to keep on going. We want it to be this year, butit isn’t we will try to win it next year.“Myself and my players know what we want and we have to set about the task of going in and doing it and hopefully we can.”Aberdeen head for Govan this evening following Saturday’s - draw with Celtic at Parkhead. It was a resolute defensive display from the Dons against the Premiership champions.McInnes is hoping his charges can deliver another showing of that ilk and keep another clean sheet against Rangers.The importance of shutting out Steven Gerrard’s side doesn’t need to be emphasised.Both victories for the Reds against the Gers this season have come when they have kept clean sheets – - at Ibrox in the league in December and by the same score in October’s League Cup semi-final.McInnes added: “When you play against good teams who like to dominate the ball like Celtic and Rangers you have to be smart with your work. You can’t give them too much space to operate because good players like space.“Both Celtic and Rangers have got good players with a lot of pace who can punish you.“If we had even resources we could go and take Celtic on and play in a certain way. But we have to find other ways to get our results and win a cup competition.“This game will be similar where we need to pick and choose our fights, be good defensively as a team but also have the courage and confidence to go and play and create chances.“We have scored against Rangers in every game we’ve played them this season, but like Celtic they’re not easy to score against.“The defensive part of the game on Saturday was good and not many teams go to Parkhead and keep a clean sheet.“The last three times we’ve gone there we’ve won -, lost - and drew -.“There’s been nothing in those games and it shows with the right concentration and enough determination you can get the desired results.”McInnes is hopeful of having wingers Gary Mackay-Steven and Niall McGinn available tonight.Both missed Saturday’s draw with Celtic, Mackay-Steven with a calf knock and McGinn with a hip problem.

title: no brom ance as mcinnes keeps all his attention on quarter final
story: Derek McInnes is fully focused on his work with Aberdeen and not looking at speculation linking him with ato West Brom.Albion boss Darren Moore, a friend and former team-mate of McInnes, was sacked on Saturday night.That is despite the Hawthorns club sitting fourth in the Championship with the possibility of promotion either automatically or through the play-offs back to the Premier League.As is customary when jobs such as West Brom become available, speculation circulates, particularly on social media, about McInnes potentially moving on from Pittodrie.However, the Dons boss, who played with Moore for Albion from -, takes no notice of the rumours and is devoting his attention to the Reds’ Scottish Cup quarter-final replay against Rangers tonight.Slavisa Jokanovic and David Wagner are among the favourites to take over at West Brom, with Scot Alex Neil also mentioned.McInnes said: “I’m gutted for Darren Moore because it’s such a harsh decision.“I spoke to him last week and it just seems so unfair on him to lose his job.“We are used to it now as managers, we are used to seeing managers lose their job unfairly.“In terms of myself and everyone  at Aberdeen, we have work to concentrate on and that’s what we’re doing.“It’s very rare that managers get much understanding or time in the modern day, but it still seems really unfair.”This evening McInnes will have to do without striker Sam Cosgrove, who is suspended.The Englishman has scored  goals this season, but is out after picking up yellow cards against Queen of the South in round five and in the initial - quarter-final draw with Rangers.Stevie May or James Wilson are set to be drafted in to replace Cosgrove. Both May and Wilson have only found the net three times this season.Although McInnes is disappointed to be without Cosgrove he sees the clash with the Gers as an opportunity for someone .He added: “Sam has been a permanent fixture for us over the last few months and has been very good.“He’s someone that we’ve turned to in a lot of big games.“He helps occupy defenders, he gives us size and strength and he gives us goals as well.“We have a squad for a reason – we’ve never been totally dependent on a particular player – our biggest strength has always been the team.“It’s up to us and others to take responsibility now to find a way to win.“We’ve been in a lot of games this season without key players.“In some cases it has maybe affected us, but in other cases it has been an opportunity for others and they have taken those opportunities so that’s what we’re hoping for in this game.”The Aberdeen defence will come up against Alfredo Morelos again at Ibrox.The Colombian striker has shown both sides of his game against the Dons. He netted twice in last month’s - Gers win at Pittodrie before getting sent off.Morelos has also been red carded on two of the three other occasions he has faced the Dons.McInnes doesn’t want to give him chances tonight and said: “It’s like with all good players, he is a good player and we’re well aware of that.“He expects to score when he goes on the pitch and is a strong competitor.“But with all Rangers’ good players we have to try to restrict their influence on the game.”This is the sixth meeting between Aberdeen and Rangers this season. The Dons have won two and lost one with the sides also having two draws.McInnes doesn’t think the familiarity of the teams and what has gone before will have an impact on the latest encounter.He said: “Whatever has happened before this season doesn’t really have any bearing on it.“I’ve always felt it’s the next game that’s most important and not games that have happened in the past.”

Maybe that has something to do with the enormity of what needs to be done.Once again our hospital beds, services for vulnerable people and other things taken for granted will be in the spotlight.The impact on staff was raised, quite rightly, at the IJB meeting, but there was no mention of the impact on patients and service users.As one NHS staff member at the meeting said: #We can bring forward savings, but what we bring back to the board might not feel very palatable.#There is a need for members of the public to have their say in changes to these public services, and a meeting in Lochgilpheadnext week will be discussing that subject.

title: letters week 06
story: Laura MaxwellUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSirWe would like to take this opportunity to thank all of those who have either given or offered assistance and support to my family following the fire at our home on the night of January , and a special thanks to the emergency services that attended.Anyone who was present either at the time or who has seen the remains will appreciate the level of destruction wrought upon our home and the contents within, however, as noted in this paper last week, all of us were unharmed and have been provided with accommodation nearby.The support given by friends, work and the wider community has been truly humbling, and as a family we thank you all and look forward to ing to our home, hopefully sometime next year.Thank you,Alan and Gillian Pitman, The Old Church, ArdrishaigSir,I must commend our MP Brendan O#Hara on his vision and wisdom on his recent fact-finding trip to the Faroe Islands to see first hand how The Faroese inter-connect their islands with  subsea and through mountain tunnels.This common sense approach guarantees safe connectivity   in any weather providing confident travel which is the least the people of Mid Argyll, Kintyre, Islay and Jura should expect. This area of Argyll is the most fragile in the region. The people of Argyll, businesses and visitors deserve no less.Forget the squandering of £m on unreliable, mitigation measures trying to justy a flawed decision made many years ago to use the Old Military Road as a ersion which has failed on many occasions and now has a landslip between the two roads. Forget the expensive excavation of pits by the A rather use the cuttings into the hillside to form a two lane road protected with a flow over canopy with closed outer edges at the four problems gullies. If the contractors on the present scheme can work without any road closures then the flow over canopy option would not lead to closures as many officials and some politicians claim.This is a red herring postponing #a proper solution#. When this is option is completed it will save on the expense of manning the ersion route involving - personnel and - vehicles, replacing expensive nettings, delays whilst the farmer clears his animals and collect his fees. A scandalous waste of public money. Solve The Rest Landslides and stop wasting on mitigating measures.Like Brendan O#Hara I#m neither an engineer or geologist but both of us are blessed with plain common sense. If the Faroese can build a tunnel at £.m per kilometre surely a simple open sided m canopy would cost considerably less. In  at Dawlish .km of double tracked railway and .km of sturdy seawall was built at a cost of £m in eight weeks. Why have we in Argyll after nine years, four dferent Transport Ministers and £m spent and still have no guaranteed safe passage   on The Rest and Be Thankful Follow the Argyll Advertiser#s campaign #Invest in the Rest#. Transport Minister Michael Matheson, Transport Scotland and our Government must abandon their obsession with mitigation measures and fund a permanent solution. We demand no less.Sir,Calls for assurances that the Rest and Be Thankful section of the A will be improved to resist future landslides were made during a session of Transport, Infrastructure and Connectivity questions in the Scottish Parliament.I quizzed transport secretary Michael Matheson, about what was discussed at the last meeting of the A Taskforce in November , and asked what assurances the Cabinet Secretary could give to local residents and businesses who rely on the A being open at all times.The Rest and Be Thankful was closed off for nine days in October  following the largest landslide in a decade, forcing road users to either take a major ersion, or to use the Old Military Road during certain hours of the day.A number of petitions were created during the period of the incident, including one by myself, calling for a permanent solution to the Rest and Be Thankful.The transport secretary said that the meeting was #full and frank#, and that there would be a #review of the potential for additional landslide mitigation measures at the Rest and Be Thankful#, and that this would be discussed at the next A Taskforce meeting in March .There was also a commitment that Argyll and Bute would be #prioritised# in the next Strategic Transport Projects Review.I welcome the assurances by the transport secretary that there will be a review of any additional measures for the Rest and Be Thankful, and that Argyll and Bute will receive priority at the next Strategic Transport Projects Review.Donald Cameron, MSPReserve forcesSir,Last issue#sletter raising concerns about the UK government’s proposed use of the army’s reserve force in the event of a no-deal Brexit is timely.In case anyone out there still thinks a no-deal Brexit is a good idea it’s worth noting that the legal authorityof Reserve Forces Act  allowing the Secretary of State to take this step requires him to establish that it is necessary #for the alleviation of distress or the story: Laura MaxwellUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSubscribe NowThe Ropework played host to this keenly contested local derby which was watched by a healthy crowd on Saturday February .And for the second time this season, Red Star and Campbeltown Pupils shared the points in a match both sides will feel they could have won.Both sides were struggling for fluency in the opening stages but Red Star settled first and grabbed the opening goal after  minutes. A long ball to the right hand side was met by Ryan Caskie who cut the ball back to Stuart McLean. The youngster took a touch before slotting past the Pupils# goalkeeper to give Star a - lead.Star continued to press and doubled their lead when Coll McCallum robbed the Pupils# defender on the edge of the box before cutting the ball across goal. The unfortunate Pupils# defender could only ert the ball into the empty net, with McLean waiting on a tap in. The game continued at a frantic pace, however, there was no further scoring in the first half and Star went in with a - advantage.Pupils came out with purpose in the second half as they looked to force themselves back into the game, however, it was a howler from Red Star which allowed them back into the match.A square ball across the back resulted in a mix-up between Star keeper Luke Kalache and defender Ben Forbes which allowed Donald McCallum to prod the ball home from just inside the box and Pupils were back in the game at - with eight second half minutes gone.The home side didn’t recover from this and you could sense a nervousness that gave the visitors plenty encouragement. title: john crawford ardrishaig
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSubscribe NowShinty in Mid Argyll has lost one of its great stalwarts with the passing of John Crawford of Ardrishaig after a short illness.John, aged , died in Mid Argyll Hospital on the evening of Thursday February .John was born and brought up in Minard in Argyll. He was a former member of shinty#s South of Scotland area executive council and did a lot of work for the Referees’ Association.He was probably best known for his work with young players in Mid Argyll, organising qualying tournaments of the Aviemore Indoor Sixes tournament for many years. His work for that competition was recognised by the organisers when he was given a special award at Aviemore along with his friend Donnie MacKenzie of Lochaber.John helped reform Kilmory shinty club in the mid s along with Ian MacPhee, the late Kenny MacRae, Roddy Munro and Alex Campbell. He also served on their committee for many years.John had served as a policeman for a short time before working in the quarry at Furnace, then going on to be a very well-known driver with Gleaner Oils, which supported many of his shinty activities with young players in Argyll.John was a great organiser and acted as goal judge in a number of senior shinty finals including the Glasgow Celtic Society Cup and notably the Camanachd Cup Final in Inverness when Gordon MacIntyre of Oban Camanachd scored his famous winner at the Bught Park.John apparently retrieved the ball from the net and lobbed another onto the park for the re-start before presenting the goal-scoring ball to Gordon after the match.John is survived by his brother Jim who played for Glasgow Police and he was pre-deceased by his we Donella. As a couple they were permanent fixtures at most shinty events in Argyll and well beyond, particularly at events involving young players.Tribute reproduced courtesy of the Camanachd Association

title: ayr rugby club near move
story: NewsAyr Rugby Club near move to new town centre base at Dam Park as they prepare to sell Millbrae homeThe Millbrae men, who top the Tennents Premiership, are in advanced talks to sell their Millbrae home and move to Dam Park in Ayr town centre.ShareByStuart Wilson:,  OCT NewsDam Park could play host to Ayr Rugby Club as soon as  "Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailBooming Ayr Rugby Club are nearing a deal to sell their Millbrae home and move to the town centre. Plans to buy council-owned Dam Park are at an advanced stage. The club, currently top of the Tennent’s Premiership, hope the bold switch will take them to the next level. Ayr would earn a multi-million pound jackpot by hiving off their own land for housing, with builder Cala Homes believed to be preferred bidder for the site. And they plan to use part of the cash for a pound, synthetic surface to be laid at their new home. Club chiefs have spent the last year in talks over a move and hope to seal the deal soon.  If the switch is rubber-stamped by South Ayrshire Council Ayr could be playing out of Dam Park as early as . One source said: “It is the move that makes sensethe club is to continue growing. “Next season sees the start of the Super Six set-up with games to be broadcast live on television. “It is potentially a great  for Ayr and bringing the club into the heart of the town can benefit so many.” The switch would see Ayr Seaforth Athletic Club on the move to a new sporting centre planned for Craigie. And junior side Whitletts Victoria couldto the heart of their community with a revamp of the old activity complex on the cards. Ayr rugby supremo Billy McHarg said talks on the move are progressing well.  He said: “Discussions to this point have been positive. “We’re keen to work with all parties to find the right solution and one which will benefit the whole town. “We feel that Ayr Rugby Club coming into the town centre would be a big step forward.” Club members would still have to approve such a move. Ayr have been at scenic Millbrae since . Prior to that they played out of Newton Park, Dam Park, the Old Racecourse and King George V playing fields. Whitletts chairman John Dalton said: “Talks have been very positive and we are currently looking at alternative options. “The football park at Whitletts is the obvious route to go down and would represent ahome to our roots. “A lot of water is still to go under the bridge but as Ayr’s junior football club we are viewing this as a positive opportunity.” Craigie councillor Ian Cavana said: “It may be that a deal is close but nobody will be moving anywhere until the new sports centre at Craigie is up and running. “Work is due to start on that next summer and that’s when we should see real progress.” A council spokesman said: “Discussions on the future of Dam Park are ongoing.”Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnSouth Ayrshire CouncilAyr NewsAyrAyr Rugby

title: bob sheilds make new recycling
story: NewsBob Shields: Make new recycling system in South Ayrshire work for usNew leaflets needed to inform the publicShareByAyrshire Post:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR News"Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAfter a first glance at last week’s report on noisy bin men – I had to check out my calendar to make sure I wasn’t getting a month ahead of myself. Let’s face it, stories about a Mr Paine and some broken glass usually appear on April . But no – it really was only March ! Mr Paine’s issue is the emptying of his street’s bottle bins at am. On the morning of his first collection, he mistook the noise of breaking glass for a robber breaking into his house. “I was terried,” he said. And then added, “This is noise pollution and most of the street must have been up.” Well, I too have suffered Mr Paine’s ‘noise pollution’ - perhaps an even noisier version. Chez Shields is no stranger to a well chilled Petit Chablis washing down the foie gras before Eastenders. In fact, I’ve been known to pop a second cork just to recover from Eastenders! Based on Mr Paine’s video recording, the noise made by the emptying of my bottle bin is right up there - somewhere between a small public house and a decent sized restaurant. Andit wakes up my neighbours – I couldn’t give a Chateau Le Clos! On my street’s first collection, I didn’t wake up thinking I was being burgled. House-breakers don’t usually make enough noise to get “most of the street up”. I seem to remember thinking, “That’ll be the bin men . . .” and going back to sleep. And on the  days a year that the glass bins are emptied in “quiet, residential Masonhill”, I respectfully suggest Mr Paine does the same. After all, we’re talking about saving the world here . . . not saving an hour’s kip! Greenhouse gas emissions are asphyxiating the planet. Plastic bags are strangling dolphins and milk bottle caps are choking sea birds. Our little Earth is throttling itself. To be honest, I’d rather be concentrating on ten decades of industrial pollution than Mr Paine’s ten minutes of noise pollution. And meanwhile, still in bin land, South Ayrshire Council is blaming the public for the latest waste collection problems. I can see the point they’re making – but the word “contamination” is a bit strong for Mrs McGuffie putting Tiddle’s empty Whiskas can in the paper and cardboard bin. And the new recycling system is a little too new for the “red tag” bin police to be targeting offenders. By refusing to lt certain bins – South Ayrshire Council is tempting fate. I’ve heard reports of some people using a neighbour’s bin when their own bin is full and red tagged. I’m also told there are increasing incidences of household waste being stuffed in the street bins reserved for pedestrian litter. And stuck in the middle are the bin men themselves. One told me “If we red tag a bin – we get **** from the householder. If we take back a contaminated bin, we get **** from our supervisors. Basically, were in the **** no matter what we do!” My dear old mum used to use a lovely phrase – “There’s a place for everything . . . .and everything in its place”. That’s exactly how SAC’s new recycling system meant to work. But it’s going to take a little time and a little patience – on both sides. The info leaflets sent out to explain the new system were largely ignored or discarded - most people didn’t understand them. But with the new bins now rolled out – a back-up leaflet might help. “You’ve got your new bins – now here’s how to use them”. Rubbishing the new rubbish system isn’t going to make it go away. It’s here – let’s get on with making it work for ourselves, our neighbours and our community.Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnAyrSouth Ayrshire CouncilEnvironment

title: churches facing end era parish
story: NewsChurches facing end of era as parish minister calls it a dayCrisis in Kirk conregationsShareByAyrshire Post:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR News"Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email There’s no parish ministers round here, writes Edwin LawrenceThat’s the crisis facing Kirk congregations in Girvan and South Carrick. And it becomes reality with the imminent departure of Rev Richard Moffat from Girvan North Parish Church. The area – in the short term at least – will be dependent on the services of elderly retired ministers and lay readers. Mr Moffat has been a popular parish minister at Girvan North for five years. And he was due to become Moderator of the Presbytery of Ayr in April. But he is set to move to a new charge in Morayshire, to be closer to his daughter and her family. He will conduct his last Sunday service in Girvan North on March . Mr Moffat’s departure is the latest factor concentrating minds in the Church of Scotland. For Girvan South, linked with Barr and Dailly is currently without its minister. Popular Rev Ian McLachlan has been on sick leave for several months. And colleagues say he is unlikely toto full-time duties. Rev Stephen Ogston was parish minister at Ballantrae Colmonell from  until August, . But he moved on to Luce Valley Church, and no replacement has been found. The linked charge of Ballantrae St Colmon also takes in services at Barrhill and Glenapp. So communities right across Girvan and South Carrick no longer have a parish minister in their midst. And there is uncertaintly at how things will be resolved. One solution might be a union of the two Girvan churches. And that could leave Girvan North - with its -foot spire – as the last kirk in town. It would presumably also be used as a hub to minister to village churches. The Post understands there can be as few as six worshippers in Barr Parish Church on Sundays. This isn’t helped by Barr being last in the pecking order for services, after Girvan South and Dailly. So it’s virtually lunchtime before a Sunday service gets under way. A Presbytery of Ayr meeting was due in the Carrick Centre in Maybole on Tuesday this week.And the Post understands this will see Rev Ian Stirling Fisherton Kirkoswald appointed interim moderator at Girvan North. Locum minister will be retired minister Rev Edgar Ogston – father of Stephen – who livesin Girvan.The Post has spoken to kirk elders in Girvan who say they’re uncertain about the future. And a retired church minister suspects that the two Girvan churches will be required to amalgamate. He said: “Things are changing. We’ve been a clergy-centred church for  years. “But one positive thing we’re seeing is the rise of worship groups which are prompting people to think about their faith, without necessarily being preached at.”Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnChurch of ScotlandAyrMoffatGirvan

title: college staging wine fuelled feast
story: NewsCollege staging wine-fuelled feast as job cuts loomLeaked emails tell of lavish bash at cash-strapped Ayrshire CollegeShareByStephen Houston:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR News"Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailCollege bosses have defended holding a celebration to honour their success amid a climate of drastic job cuts and cash problems. Ayrshire College supremos and invited senior staff will stage a sit-down feast later this month to mark five years since its formation. The dinner for  will also include free wine after a sponsored deal by college chairman Willie Mackie. Leaked emails state the claim the college is “now regarded as one of the most successful colleges in Scotland.” But our inside source said: “It adds insult to injury that this celebration is being held less than one week before the final jobs structure is issued to staff. “It is in extremely poor taste given the circumstances of potential job losses due to lack of funds.” Evening classes are having to be cancelled so the event can be staged at the Kilmarnock campus on March . Retiring principal Heather Dunk is also to be honoured during the evening. Chairman Willie Mackie said: “She has made a signicant contribution to Ayrshire for over  years.” Ms Dunk retired on February , leaving an impending restructure which will cost jobs. A consultation ends tomorrowand it has emerged the Private Finance Initiative which built the Kilwinning campus is a huge drain on funds. An email which Ms Dunk sent to staff in January read: “We need to make signicant savings to be financially sustainable due to the costs associated with the PFI, unfunded national bargaining costs and the increasing costs of pensions, utilities and other services. I am very disappointed that an organisational review is necessary, it is not what I want to be focused on in my last weeks as principal. “However, we must manage within the financial allocation we receive in this very dficult fiscal climate.” Under the consultation, one of the four vice-principals would be axed, three directors culled, heads of learning cut from  to nine, and three marketing coms staff would go. Also at risk of the chop are two posts within estates as well as a shake-up of duties among departments. The board of management will approve the final structure and staff impacted will get a severance package. Ayrshire College acknowledged finance was a major challenge for all Scottish colleges but said the dinner costs were met by sponsorship. A spokeswoman said: “Our main financial challenge for the year ahead is to meet the costs associated with the Kilwinning PFI Campus, national bargaining costs and the increasing costs of pensions, utilities and services. “While the Scottish Funding Council has agreed to provide further strategic funds to help manage these rising costs, the college still requires to make signicant savings to secure its financial sustainability and jobs for the future. “We are, therefore, considering proposals for an organisational review. “All staff are aware of the challenges the college faces, and have contributed to a consultation regarding potential efficiencies and opportunities for income generation. “We have just passed our five-year anniversary as Ayrshire College, and have planned an event, ‘Celebrating Five Years of Success. It is important to recognise this milestone and celebrate success – for learners, staff, the college and the region. “We are mindful of the costs of holding such an event and so have secured full sponsorship.”Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnUniversities and CollegesAyr NewsAyrEducationKilmarnockSchoolsKilwinning

title: first minister must act over
story: NewsFirst Minister must act over Tarbolton landfill, says MSPThe South of Scotland Tory MSP says he is hearing growing concerns from villagers about the condition of the site.ShareByAyrshire Post:,  MAR NewsBrian Whittle MSP challenges the First Minister in the Scottish Parliament "Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailMore than eight months after Tarbolton Landfill’s owners entered liquidation, MSP Brian Whittle has challenged the First Minister to act, writes Edwin Lawrence. The South of Scotland Tory MSP says he is hearing growing concerns from villagers about the condition of the site. He said: “Since the landfill closed its gates, worries have been expressed about smells and also about contaminated water running off the site.” These would normally be dealt with by the site owner, so Mr Whittle took up the issue with both the Scottish Environment Protection Agencyand the Scottish Government. However, in the absence of a clear answer on ultimate responsibility, he decided to raise it at Holyrood, during First Minister’s questions. In response, First Minister Nicola Sturgeon said:   “I am not able to give that information to Brian Whittle right now. “I undertake to raise the issue with the environment secretary and to come back to Brian Whittle as quickly as possible about our understanding of the lines of accountability and the action that the Scottish Government can take to try to reach a resolution of what certainly seems to be a deeply unsatisfactory situation. “I can understand that people in the local area will be very concerned about any prospect of contamination and it is absolutely necessary that all relevant agencies and organisations respond as quickly as possible.” Speaking afterwards, Brian Whittle MSP said: “The situation with the Tarbolton Landfill has been allowed to drag on for too long already. “Aside from the obvious concerns local residents have, it’s troubling that there doesn’t appear to be a clearly defined process for when the operator of a site like this is no longer able to carry out their duties to protect the surrounding environment. “I hope the First Minister will be able to provide some much needed clarity on this issue.”

title: giant bins placed right outside
story: NewsGiant bins placed right outside a restaurant and pub in scenic townAnger in Troon as bin squad set up town corral without asking anyone for permissionShareByStephen Houston:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR News "Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA council works gang put up a new big bin enclosure – right outside a restaurant and pub in the scenic centre of town. Now a row has broken out after it emerged one council department had not even bothered to speak to another. The unsightly corral cluster for five bins was secured in place near The Cross in Troon without any consultation. Troon Councillors have now become aware after a multitude of complaints. The cleansing department is claiming they contacted the planning department about the placing of the bins. But planners are denying any knowledge of a consultation. Troon SNP Councillor Craig Mackay is now leading the charge to find somewhere  for the bins to be situated, rather than outside the Jade Garden Chinese and Macintyre’s bar. He is asking for officials to meet councillors at the spot in Templehill to try and find a resolution. Councillor Mackay said: “We are trying to develop a coherent vision for our town centre. “I’m not convinced this is the best we can manage for such a high profile location. Cleansing regrettably installed these enclosures without any prior consultation. While it is arguably an operational matter that doesn’t require any such input,they had asked any of the councillors or the community council for comment then I am certain we would not have found ourselves in this situation. “The council’s Planning service disappointingly also appear not to have been consulted on the siting or design of this bin store within the conservation area. I don’t wish to play departments off against each other, but would seek to find a community consensus about what is appropriate for our public realm. “This will almost certainly involve an alternative solution for the bins.” A council spokesman confirmed they are investigating, saying: ““We introduced communal bins to keep the litter secure and away from gulls. The early indications are that this system is working well, however we are currently reviewing the location of the bins.”Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnScottish National PartyTroonAyrAyr News

title: look out sooty sweep heading
story: NewsLook out, Sooty and Sweep are heading to AyrStage show insists laughs will come thick and fast at Ayr GaietyShareByStephen Houston:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR News "Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailSooty is set to SWEEP into Ayr next month. The wee silent man will be on stage with his squeeky pal Sweep and chatterbox Soo. TheirRichard Cadell will lead events at The Gaiety in Ayr on April . It’s being billed as a brand new Laugh Out Loud Magic Show. Sooty takes to the air in a flying car, Soo has a singing unicorn and Sweep has something altogether dferent. He has a levitating sausage, which certainly creates a vision. Special guests circus star Michael Jordan and the ultraviolet specialties of Fantasie de la Nuit promise a thrilling -minute show. Tickets are between pound and pound and there are two shows – am and .pm. Sooty has celebrated his th birthday and Richard says he’s still as young as ever. Richard revealed: “This show is Sooty doing what he does best – magic. “So the Gaiety audience can expect to be saying ‘Izzy whizzy let’s get busy’ a great deal. “Sooty will be performing some amazing tricks including sawing a lady in half, floating a child from the audience and making it snow. “Sweep will be getting in the way with his own disastrous magic tricks most of which revolve around sausages.” He added: “Performing live is what we love most. Of course, making the television show is a lot of fun but Sooty has always been at his best in front of a live audience where he can make not only the children laugh, but all the adults too. Plus after each performance there is a chance for everybody to meet Sooty and it’s always such a pleasure to meet fans old and new.” Sooty and Sweep performed for Prince Charles for his th birthday. Richard added: “I think it was possibly the highlight of Sooty’s career. title: galashiels-shows-sweet-charity-love
story: SWEET Charity may be about a down-on-her-luck dancehall hostess searching for love.But there was certainly a lot of it coming from the Volunteer Hall audience at the end of Galashiels Operatic Amateur Societyrsquos opening show on Monday night.Led this year by Carla McColgan, the group put on another faultless performance. The story focusses on protagonist Charity Hope Valentine who is desperate to find her Mr Right.She works at the seedy Fandango Ballroom but has dreams of moving on to bigger things.But it may eventually be the performers themselves who reach the top ndash as their talent shone all evening. In the opening scenes Carla, Jan Bairdand Ruth Davidsonwowed the sell-out crowd with their renditions of classics including You Should See Yourself and Big Spender.And just when it looked as though Charity may have found the one when she meets Italian film star Vittorio Vidal, played by Jack McAulay, she ends up spending the night in his closet as his partner Ursulas home.The cast mastered their American accents, while Jackrsquos Italian twang seemed second nature. And he also impressed with his powerful performance of Too Many Tomorrows.Charity however gets her second chance when she gets stuck in a lt with Oscar ndash a claustrophobic accountant hilariously played by Clark Eaton Turner.Clark is no stranger to the Volunteer Hall stage, and it is clear that the versatile actor can turn his hand to anything. Everything looks well for the dance hall hostess, as Oscar proposes.But the wedding plans are dropped ndash and Charity has to find happiness within herself.On an evening of such commanding performances, it can be easy to forget the people who also work so hard behind the scenes to create this spectacle.Producer and musical director Jeff Thomson deserves huge credit as does choreographer Marie McCullough who obviously worked tirelessly.The sets are brilliantly designed and the scene-changes are swt. The orchestra was also given a deserved ovation at the end. There wasnrsquot a note out of place.Sweet Charity is running this week at the Volunteer Hall, Galashiels, until Saturday, March .
